properties.Name: 10 Plus
properties.Story: Established in 1994, 10 Plus was a cruising venue with two buildings and outdoor garden for cruising.

properties.Name: 100 Years of Queer History at 260 Collins Street
properties.Story: Although venues changed, were demolished or rebuilt, 260 Collins Street has over 100 years of queer history. The first even happened the the Vienna Café (1890-1915). A popular venue with theatre celebrities and famous men, The Vienna Café was the site of the 1908 arrest of three men dressed in drag.  Alan McKail (20) Douglas Ogilvie (22) and Tom Page (25) were arrested and charged with behaving indecently in a public place, when they dressed as women and entered the Vienna Café for a private meal. The judge called them "sexual perverts, or damn young fools" stating that "the difference between male and female apparel was one of the cornerstones of civilisation and no one could be allowed to flaunt that convention".  But this would just be the start of the locations to queer history.  Following various rebuilds and demolition, the construction of the Australian Hotel (1930s-1979) lead to much more overt queer behaviours. The Club Bar on the first floor of the Australian Hotel was a popular gay bar, busy on Friday and Saturday Nights. It was frequented by "Social Queens" such as window dressers from Myers and suit wearing "Travel Industry Queers".  This contrasted the basement level bar called the Pink Sink and later The Snakepit, a gay venue known for rough trade and butch types. Recently released prisoners were known to solicit sex work at Snake Pit and there were cases of theft. There was little cross over between the patrons of the bars, but as these venue closed early due the laws at the time, the pavement of Collins Street was filled with queers quietly exchanging the address of secret parties where they could continue to socialise and even dress in drag.  The Tatler Theatre on the bottom level of the Australia Hotel was also a beat popular with queer men. On the 17th of February, 1951, Edward Meyer (27) was arrested for offensive behaviour after groping a police officer in the theatre. Initially grabbing the policeman's thigh, before moving his hand, Meyer is reported to have said "'I haven't much time today. We'll have to hurry. I've done enough for one day and time is short". He was fined and jailed for 14 days,In 1970, The Snakepit was renovated and renamed the Woolshed in hopes of attracting a heterosexual crowd.  The new rugged interiors inspired by the Australian outback were a hit with the cruising gays who had frequented The Snakepit.  Quickly the Woolshed became the 'the best known meeting place for gay people' in Melbourne. The renovation although not deterring the queer patronage, did change the image of the bar and patrons from the City Bar upstairs began going downstairs to the Woolshed and vice versa. After ten years the Woolshed closed on the 8 September 1979, its closure punctuated by the arrest of Terry Stokes and Darren Turner outside the venue for kissing. Both were later charged with offensive behaviour in the Melbourne Magistrates' Court. In 1988-92 the Australia Hotel and the Royal Arcade Hotels were demolished, being replaced by Australia-on-Collins. Still the gays could not be uttered, and the men's bathrooms became a cruising site for office workers during their lunch breaks. The site was closed in 2014, demolished and redeveloped as St Collins Lane, which has continued to be cruising location.

properties.Name: 55 Porter Street
properties.Story: An integral part of Melbourne's Sauna scene for over 20 years, 55 Porter was a popular sex on premises venue in Prahran.

properties.Name: 7th Heaven
properties.Address: Russell St & Lonsdale St, Melbourne VIC 3000
properties.Story: The original venue of 7th Heaven, Zuzu's hosted the night before it moved to thr Cadillac Bar.

properties.Name: 7th Heaven
properties.Story: 7th Heaven Sundays found a new home at the Cadillac Bar on Swanston St. One of Melbourne's most missed night clubs, 7th Heaven was known for its racy flyers and fabulous performances. 7th hosted performers such as Miss Candee, Victoria Bitter, Millie Minogue, Paris, Rita, Babet, Bob Down, Levi Jones and Barbara Quicksand.

properties.Name: Abode
properties.Story: Abode hosts events for the alternative kink scene of the south side. Although not exclusively queer, the events welcome and are popular with the queer community.

properties.Name: Ad Lib (1964-1965)
properties.Story: Val Eastwood (of Val's on Swanston) opened Ad Lib as a discreet meeting-place for sections of the gay community as a new venture after the sale of her other location.  Hidden away during the day, Ad Lib came to life in the late afternoons and again welcomed the queer community to a place they relax with others like themselves, just this time with Italian inspired food.

properties.Name: AIDS Memorial Garden
properties.Story: In the bushland behind what was Fairfield Hospital, a garden was dedicated to people living with AIDS. Fairfield Hospital was one of the main sites for treatment and care of AIDS patients. In 1985 the construction of a garden to give patients, families and friends a break from the hospital and thoughts of disease was the idea of one of the care teams of the AIDS ward. Working with Thorne Harbour Health (previously the Victorian Aids Council), the garden was constructed. Donations came from Ken Payne (owner of Mandate, St Kilda), Ian Ross (architect of gazebo), the VAC Management Committee, Randall Robinson (botanist), Northcote City Council and families who has lost members to AIDS.  The site was intended for use of patients at Fairfield, however ashes of patients had been scattered at the site and various memorial plaques had been installed. Following the closure of Fairfield Hospital, the site fell into disrepair and through the determination of community members Mannie De Saxe and Kenall Lovett the site was reinstated in 2010 with Melbourne Polytechnic (formerly the Northern Melbourne Institute of TAFE who now use the Fairfield Hospital site) now caring for the area.

properties.Name: Albert Park Beat
properties.Story: Under the cover of the darkness, Albert Park was a common meeting place for queer men. But one had to careful of officers policing the area and anything that may indicate you had been committing buggery. In 1925, Ernest Casey (45) and James Moore (18) raised the suspicions of police as they exited the reserve, heading toward Fitzroy street for some food.  Unfortunately, Moore's grass stained and damp knees exposed their previous actions and Casey was charged with buggery.

properties.Name: Aleph Melbourne
properties.Story: The 2017 St Kilda FIlm Festival screened the film “Aleph Melbourne – Celebrating 20 Years”, a collaboration between Aleph Melbourne and YouthWorx Productions. The documentary shared the 20 year history, memorabilia, interviews and amazing outcomes of Aleph. Founded in 1995, Aleph begun as a support and social group for Jewish gay men coming to terms with their sexuality.  It has since developed to include all members of the queer spectrum and has been actively involved with the Midsumma Pride March.

properties.Name: Alexandra Gardens Beat
properties.Story: Alexandra Gardens was a popular cruising area from the 1920s.

properties.Name:
Alice Anderson’s
Grave
properties.Story: In 1919, Alice Anderson established the first women's garage in Kew.  Here she employed a fully female team to repair motor vehicles - work that had traditionally been viewed as the work of men. Anderson and her staff dressed in a masculine manner wearing peaked caps, leather jackets, boots and trousers.  She is rumoured to be have been a lesbian but there is no substantial evidence.  Alice was shot while at the garage, however no one was prosecuted for her death.  She was buried at the Boroondara Cemetery in Kew. Alice Anderson Motor Service continued after her death, before closing in the 1940s due to World War II.

properties.Name: ALSO Party Location
properties.Address: Station Peer, Port Phillip Bay, VIC
properties.Story: One of the many locations that hosted the ALSO parties such as Red Raw, Winter Daze, Women's Own Warehouse Parties and their New Years Eve Party.  These parties not only were not only important events in the queer calendar but great employers of queer people, the heterosexual party world not wanting to be associated with a queer crowd.  ALSO's parties also informed the future of Melbourne's dance party and rave scene, being a case study for heterosexual and queer promoters on how to do it right.

properties.Name: ALSO Party Location

properties.Name: Archbishop George Pell rejecting Rainbow Sash Movement members from communion (1998)
properties.Story: On Pentecost Sunday 31 May 1998 a group of 70 people attended Mass in St Patrick's Cathedral, Melbourne, wearing a Rainbow Sash to protest the refusal of London's Cardinal Basil Hume, Melbourne's Archbishop George Pell and Cardinal John O'Connor, to provide communion to two openly gay Catholic men in 1987. They were once again rejected from communion by Archbishop George Pell. This would be the first of many attempts by the group to give voice to LGBT+ community in the catholic church and ask for reforms around sexuality. Key campaigners include Michael B. Kelly, Geoffrey Baird, David Barker, Ivan Tchernegovski, and David McKenna.

properties.Name: Arrest of Fred Lee (1926)
properties.Story: Fred Lee worked at the Austral Cafe in Exhibition Street as a resident shoe shiner, although this may have been code for another role. In 1926 he was approached by Ernest Pollard (18) who requested his shoes shined, Lee took Pollard to a back room of the café and began his service, which included oral sex.  Pollard, once he reached completion, left the cafe and approached the police officer reporting the indecent act. Lee was sentenced and served three months at Pentridge Prison.

properties.Name: Arrest of George Lawrence (1888)
properties.Story: In 1888, whilst attending the International Exhibition at the Exhibition Buildings dressed in drag, George Lawrence was arrested by police.  Although it is uncertain whether the police officers thought he was a female sex worker or knew he was in drag, all was revealed when his wig fell. Lawrence was initially charged with Insulting Behaviour before this was upped to Vagrancy, leading him to a six month prison term.

properties.Name: Arrest of James Gore and Selwyn Lindsay (1925)
properties.Story: In March of 1925, James Gore and Selwyn Lindsay were arrested in Wright's Lane (later renamed Hardware Lane), when they were found in a doorway, Gore with no pants and Lindsay on his knees.  Both pleading innocence, they were later convicted and served 15 months hard labour at Pentridge

properties.Name: Arrest of John Wilson (1863)
properties.Address: Brunswick Street & Victoria Parade East Melbourne VIC 3002
properties.Story: On the 10th of October 1863, John Wilson (who was dressed in drag and soliciting sex work from a man) was approached by police. Running down Victoria Parade, Wilson tried to escape and continued these attempts even after being caught during transportation to Fitzroy Police Station. After police investigation and statements from seven local men who had paid Wilson for sex while dressed as a woman, Wilson was charged with sodomy.  He was found guilty of the "abominable crime of buggery", which was punishable by the death sentence but in Wilson's case became life imprisonment. He served six years at Pentridge Prison before passing away at 43 in 1969.

properties.Name: Arrest of Percy Haynes (1958)
properties.Story: In the August of 1958, Percy Haynes decided to dress as a woman and try and pass in public. After getting dressed and putting on makeup,he travelled into the city via tram, spending the day shopping in Collins Street and the Manchester Unity Building. During his shopping trip, a police officer began to follow Haynes, going so far as to trail him into the Tatler theatre in the Hotel Australia and stay for the whole showing.  When Haynes headed home, again my tram, the police officer followed, waiting until Haynes was at his front gate to knock off his wig and arrest him.  Haynes was arrested for Offensive Behaviour but due to the lenient Magistrate waived the charge and Haynes walked free.  Haynes had not behaved inappropriately while in public having not interacted with anyone.  The Magistrate even commented how respectable Haynes had dressed. Although drag would not be normalised for many years to come, this case demonstrates a changing of attitude in Australian society.

properties.Name: Arrest of queer men at beat (2009)
properties.Story: In 2009, seven men were arrested for lewd conduct and indecent exposure after community concern about the increase of sexual behaviour within the park.

properties.Name: Arrest of Robert Storer
properties.Story: In 1942, Robert Storer faced charges of gross indecency with an 18-year old soldier after police had spied through the keyhole of Storer’s flat in Alcaston House. Storer - a bisexual Australian doctor, sex educator and writer - famously wrote books popularising and promoting the idea that bisexuality and homosexuality are a part of the normal range of human sexuality. His texts were often critised, sometimes bringing him to court.  However, they were some of the first Australian texts to present homosexuality as a matter of taste and that it was in fact normal.

properties.Name: Beat Books (1979 -)
properties.Story: Reported as 'Melbourne's first gay shopfront', Beat Books is a bookstore with an upstairs cruising area.

properties.Name: Bifocal Newsletter
properties.Story: Published in the mid-1990s, Bifocal was a hardcopy newsletter produced by the Bisexual Awareness Melbourne (BAM). BAM was established in 1994 and demonstrated a new wave of Bisexual Pride that had not been seen during the Gay Liberation and Radicalesbian movements of the 70s. Bifocal, addressed issues of direct relevance to bisexuals. How can you live a queer life in an opposite sex relationship? Why do bisexual people sometimes feel unwelcome at gay and lesbian events? Bifocal also reveals the expansion of mainstream gay and lesbian organisations, such as Midsumma, to include bisexual representation. There are known to be twelve issues of Bifocal produced between June 1994 and October 1996.

properties.Name: Big In Fashion

properties.Name: Bijou Theatre Arcade Beat
properties.Story: The bathrooms of the Bijou Theatre Arcade were a beat. The men's bathrooms drew attention in 1921 following the arrest of John Smith (56), who had unsuccessfully approached businessman Dennis Dunn for some mutual masturbation.  Dunn reported Smith to a police officer, after following him another beat location and back to the Bijou, where he had approached another man. Smith faced six months imprisonment.

properties.Name: Blades at Annabel's Hotel (1975-1976)
properties.Story: Once home to the German Club and the Naval and Military Club, Annabel's hotel was the venue of Blades - a queer social club on Sunday nights. Members only ($1.50 Membership fee), Blades was a meeting place for the queer community between 1975-1976 where they could watch drag performances, eat and drink. Blades was mixed but also hosted women only evenings. Touted as having "the best lighting effects in the Melbourne Gay scene" by Honey B in CAMPAIGN, Blades members enjoyed the glamourous experience of colonial carved wooden furniture, aquamarine decor and even a a colour TV.

properties.Name: Bluestone Beat
properties.Address: Acland St & Shakespeare Grove St Kilda VIC 3182
properties.Story: Before its removal, as part of preparations for the Grand Prix, a large bluestone toilet block stood on the corner.  Frequented by many queer men, the site was a popular beat.

properties.Story: In 1952 Val, of Val’s Coffee Lounge, opened Café 31, the second of her venues.  Val recognised the queer community presence in St Kilda, as well as how well the bohemian audience suited her camp cafes that hosted live performance.

properties.Address: Catani Gardens, Beaconsfield Parade, St Kilda West VIC 3182

properties.Name: Chevron Hotel
properties.Story: Home of the 70s disco Babes, the 80s disco Chaps and the 90s nightclub Dome run by the drag queen Miss Jane, Chevron had many queer iterations before it was converted to apartments. Notable attendees of Babes include designer Alannah Hill.

properties.Name: Christ’s Community Church
properties.Story: Christ’s Community Church (CCC) was formed in October 1973 as a study group set up to explore the relationship between Christianity and homosexuality. This study group became the The Melbourne Metropolitan Community Church congregation, before splintering in July 1976. Four of the original members of the study group left MCC, formed CCC and asked Reverend John Willis to pastor for them. Initially, CCC met for weekly worship at the Anglican Chaplaincy Students’ Church in Carlton. But they were evicted from there and from a series of meeting spaces that followed.  They later found a home when John Willis etablished the Hub.

properties.Name: Cinderella's
properties.Story: Cinderella's was a nightly cafe run by an elderly lady called Cinders.  Dressed in black she would welcome guests to the venue, choosing who would be allowed inside and often turning away heterosexuals.  Inside she would prepare guests tea and raisin toast, giving many young queers the opportunity to socialise in safety.

properties.Name: Circumstance

properties.Name: City East Newsagency
properties.Story: One of the largest distributors of printed gay related media such as the Gay Community News and OutRage, City East Newsagency was a way for people to connect to queer stories in print.  There was also a large selection of pornographic materials on VCR for sale and rent at the back of the store.

properties.Name: City of Darebin Rainbow Flag
properties.Story: In 2015, Darebin City Council voted to actively support the Australian campaign for same-sex marriage. The council's support of the campaign was so strong that in May 2017, the council voted to raise a rainbow flag over Preston Town Hall as an expression of its support for human rights and for the health and wellbeing of LGBTIQ+ people. The flag remained in place until marriage equality was achieved. In 2018, the flag was lowered and transferred to the Darebin Heritage Library Collection to be preserved ‘as a significant heritage object’.

properties.Name: Cloud 9
properties.Story: Cloud 9 was a queer venue written about in the Sybylla Press published 'Lesbian Newsletter'

properties.Name: Club 397
properties.Story: 397 was nightclub in the 80's. On Thursday nights it was women only and was called The Boulevard

properties.Name: CLUB80
properties.Story: CLUB80 was a mens only sex of premisis venue spread across four floors that opened in the 80s. They offered a number of facilities for cruising and filthy play, including 16 private private rooms for rent. In 1998 The Laird and Club 80 were granted 'Male-only' status by the Victorian Civil and Administrative Tribunal. CLUB80 closed when the building was sold to developers.

properties.Name: Corrective Hair Centre

Call the After Hours phone for an appointment."

properties.Name: Courage
properties.Story: Courage is a bronze statue by artist William Eicholtz dedicated to the legacy of Ralph McLean, described as ‘Australia’s first openly gay elected official (City of Fitzroy, 1982) and Mayor (1984), an advocate for gay rights and social justice, and a champion of the arts'. It was unveiled as part of the official cultural program of the 20th International AIDS Conference in Melbourne. Referencing the Cowardly Lion in The Wizard of Oz and is set on a ‘dance floor’ base that lights up like the yellow brick road.

properties.Name: Cruising at the Princes Bridge
properties.Address: Princes Bridge, St Kilda Rd, Melbourne VIC 3000
properties.Story: In the 1920s and 30s, Princes Bridge was used as a cruising destination at night by queer men.  Conveniently located near the beat at Alexandra Gardens, the busy spot allowed for subtle communication in crowds, before a disappearance to the darkness of the Gardens.

properties.Name: D-Day protest at the Floral Clock
properties.Story: On June 6th, 1991 the Melbourne faction of ACT UP (a group of activisits opposed to the lack of action by the Australian Government to make the latest drug treatments for the those living with HIV and AIDS available) staged a direct action protest. Holding various D-Day (Deaths, Delays, Drugs and Deadline) protests around the city. The group begun their schedule with a pre-dawn strike on the famed Floral Clock in the Queen Victoria Gardens.  The group pulled up all of the flowers, replacing them with white crosses - to symbolise the deaths caused by the government's inaction of HIV/AIDS policy - and a banner that read "ACT UP we won't wait.".  This protest was widely criticised in mainstream and queer media as going too far, ACT UP members even facing harassment in queer venues. However, the protest did draw the attention of the public to the issues of those living with HIV and AIDS.

properties.Name: Daughters of Bilitis
properties.Story: First clubhouse known to be frequented by the Daughters of Bilitis

properties.Name: Debate on the legalisation of homosexuality (1964)
properties.Story: In 1964, the Debating Union of Melbourne University held a debate on the legalisation of homosexuality. For the decriminalisation was AA Bartholemew, Patrick McCaughy and Gary Evans. Against the decriminalisation was Mr Clifford Pannam, Michael Redfern and Peter Carter. The Australian reported that the final vote in favour of decriminalisation was 281 to 98, although these figures are debated. But despite their accuracy, when later reported there was support for decriminalisation from The President of the NSW Humanist Society, the Professor of Philosophy and the warden of St Paul's College of the University of Sydney and the Anglican Archbishop of Melbourne Dr Frank Woods. In many ways, the debate got the ball rolling for the decriminalisation of homosexuality in Victoria.

properties.Name: Decriminalisation of Homosexual Sex between men (1980)
properties.Story: In mid 1975, Labor MP Barry Jones introduced homosexual law reform to the Victorian Parliament.  South Australia had recently decriminalised homosexuality and following their lead, Jones would use a Private Member Bill to advocate for reform. In 1976 the Homosexual Law Reform Coalition was created and drew great publicity following the arrest of 100 men at Black Rock Beach over the summer of 1976 -1977 for "loitering with homosexual intent".  Although Liberal Premier Rupert Hamer and Attorney General Haddon Storey indicated support for reform by the end of 1976, it took until the 18th of December 1980 for the decriminalisation of homosexual sex between men to pass parliament.  Opposition from Liberal MPs, crossing the floor to vote against the bill or to add amendments slowed the bill's initial process. The law came into effect on the 1st of March 1981 and initial amendments by the Liberal party were repealed in 1985 by the Labor Government to decriminalize all homosexual sex acts.

properties.Name: Dover Hotel
properties.Address: Corner of Lygon & Victoria Streets, Carlton
properties.Story: A popular venue in the gay 70s

properties.Name: DT's Hotel
properties.Story: Dt's is a welcoming venue for everyone. It is predominantly gay, but is also popular with the trans and cross dressing commmunity. DT's hosts events such as an Annual Drag Ball and is sometimes visited by its notable neighbour Molly Meldrum.

properties.Name: Eagle Leather
properties.Story: Eagle Leather is an iconic Melbourne fetish store that is the benchmark BDSM fetish company in Australia. It has been running for 25+ years, servicing LGBTQI+ people interested in kink, BDSM, leather, and sex toys.

properties.Name: El Sombrero (1957-1963)
properties.Story: Known by ASIO to have been a hangout spot for lesbians within the WRAAF (Women's Royal Australian Air Force). As female homosexuality was not illegal at the time, Police only apprehended them on suspicion of prostitution and associating with undesirables (homosexual men).

properties.Name: Establishment of the Gay Liberation Front (1972)
properties.Address: Union House, Tin Alley, University of Melbourne, Parkville VIC 3010
properties.Story: Following a visit to Melbourne by Dennis Altman, author of Homosexual: Oppression and Liberation, the The Melbourne University Gay Liberation Front was established in 1972.  Attendees of the original meeting included Rodney Thorpe, Julian Desailly, Peter McEwan, Sasha Soldatow, Jeffrey Hill, Rex Rohmer and Jude Munro.  The Liberation Front originally met in the Undergraduate and Graduate Lounges on the second floor of the union building.  Later they would rent spaces in Fitzroy and Carlton as a way to expand membership outside of the university.

properties.Name: Establishment the Troll Dolls
properties.Story: Various venues in it's time, the Duke of Albany Hotel (Dukes Hotel) was the birthplace of Kerrie Le Gore's the Troll Dolls with Coco, Chanel and Timber. Created in 1983, the group was established when the Duke put out a call that they were looking for three drag queens to host a show.

properties.Name: Facemakers
properties.Address: 152 Church Street, Middle Brighton. Ask for Helga.

properties.Name: Fairfield Infectious Diseases Hospital (1984-1996)
properties.Story: Fairfield Infectious Diseases Hospital (now the site of Melbourne Polytechnic) was the last specific infectious disease hospital in Australia.  Fairfield Professor Ian Gust developed tests to detect HIV infection in collaboration with Dr Luc Montagnier which allowed Fairfield to begin testing for HIV before the rest of the world. The first case of AIDS at Fairfield was in April of 1984, patient numbers would increase to over 10,000 a year during the 1980s. in the 1990s Fairfield was also the site of research into the benefits to combination therapy to treat HIV.  Fairfield closed in 1996, the HIV services moving to The Alfred and Royal Melbourne Hospitals.

properties.Name: First CAMP Meeting (1971)
properties.Story: Chapter House was the location of the first meeting of CAMP (later Society Five).  Originally named as the Campaign Against Moral Persecution (CAMP) after the Sydney group that inspired it, they later changed their name to Society Five. Society Face campaigned on behalf of the queer community and offered telephone counselling.  It disbanded in 1981.

properties.Name: Fitzroy Gardens
properties.Address: Fitzroy Gardens, Wellington Parade, East Melbourne VIC 3002
properties.Story: Fitzroy Gardens was a popular cruising area from the 1920s.

properties.Name: Fitzroy's Rainbow Crossing
properties.Story: Painted in 2014, Fitzroy's rainbow crossing at the corner of Gertrude and Smith Street welcomed delegates to the International AIDS Conference held in Melbourne that year. The crossing would later become Melbourne's makeshift memorial to the 49 lives lost in the Pulse nightclub shooting in Orlando, Florida.

properties.Name: Flagstaff Gardens
properties.Story: Flagstaff Gardens was a popular cruising area from the 1920s.

properties.Name: Fleurs Lingerie
properties.Address: Warringal Village Centre, Cnr Burgundy and Cape Streets, Heidelberg
properties.Story: Foundation and Lingerie. Featured in the 1987 Seahorse Shopping Guide, this store/service was known to be Transgender and Seahorse Club friendly. The listings would also mention particular people to ask for, as they were known to be allies of the community.
properties.Source: Professor Noah Riseman, Australian Catholic University c/o Seahorse Victoria Shopping Guide

properties.Name: Founding location of The Women’s Circus and POW Circus and Memorial Bench
properties.Story: In the April of 1991, Donna Jackson established The Women's Circus at the Footscray Community Arts Centre. Her aim was to establish a circus where all womyn would learn circus, music, technical and performance skills in a feminist environment, as well as perform in their own ground-breaking shows. This was later followed by the 1995 creation of The Performing Older Women’s (POW) Circus by Jean Taylor. This group focused on teaching circus skills to womyn over 40.  As a way of honouring the memory of all the late womyn who took active and creative roles in both the Women’s Circus and POW Circus a Memorial Bench was installed at the site in 2010.

properties.Name: Galleon Cafe
properties.Story: The Galleon Cafe was a popular cafe with queer people and those that were fans of jazz.  It was also the location where Zazu Pitts, a St Kilda drag queen, would spend an evening before being witness to a suicide.  Following their night out, Zazu and a friend went for a drive around Melbourne before finding a man sitting on the edge of Queens Bridge. Trying to console him, Zazu approached the man, but he was already decided.  Thankfully for Zazu, the case was ruled as a misadventure and she was free to go.

properties.Name: Gay Liberation Centre
properties.Story: One of the homes of the Gay Liberation Front, this was the location of their 1975 fundraising parties.  Dances and parties were a great way for the front to establish connections with new people and involve them with gay liberation.

properties.Name: Gay Liberation Centre
properties.Story: One of the homes of the Gay Liberation Front, this was the location of their 1975 fundraising parties.  Dances and parties were a great way for the front to establish connections with new people and involve them with gay liberation.

properties.Name: Gay Liberation Dances at The Block Arcade (1973)
properties.Story: The Gay Liberation Front moved their dances from the Trophy Hall at Melbourne University to the Melburnian Receptions at the Block Arcade. A particular dance of note was the 1973 Gay Pride Week dance with a 'Gender Confusion' theme.

properties.Name: Gay Liberation Dances at Trophy Hall
properties.Story: The Gay Liberation Front initially held dances here in the Trophy Hall, one of their main ways to attract to new members to the cause. Although there were issues with the caretaker of the site, Melbourne University was in support of the group and the dances went ahead.

properties.Name: Gay Liberation Demonstration (1972)
properties.Story: On Friday the 1 December 1972 there was a Gay Liberation Demonstration at City Square. The demonstration begun on a tram ride to the city, then at City Square they distributed leaflets and their newspaper. The group then moved down Collins and Elizabeth Street to the GPO spelling out "homosexual"and "gay liberation" in human letters.  The group then splintered and each visited hotels and shopping centres to spread their message.

properties.Name: Gay Liberation Picnic (1973)
properties.Address: Central Lawn, Royal Botanic Gardens Victoria, Melbourne VIC 3004
properties.Story: In the second week of September, 1973 the Gay Liberation Front help a Gay Pride Week celebration. The celebrations included a Picnic at the Botanical Gardens which was attended by 150 gays and lesbians, some even dressing in radical drag (drag not to impersonate a man or woman but to question gender ideals) and holding hands in public. The picnic was a success and was only momentarily interrupted by a sole police officer who had issue with the games being played by the group.

properties.Name: GayDay (1980-1985)
properties.Address: CitiPower Centre Junction Oval, Lakeside Dr, St Kilda VIC 3182
properties.Story: The Alternative Lifestyle Organisation (ALSO) - who held events such as Raw Hide (later Red Raw) and Winter Daze - established GayDay to celebrate the decriminalisation of homosexuality. The event was publicly promoted as a gay event and help in public at the Junction Oval, differing from their previous more secretive events. Gay Day was held from 1980-1985.

properties.Name: Gilmour's Shoes
properties.Story: Shoes. Featured in the 1987 Seahorse Shopping Guide, this store/service was known to be Transgender and Seahorse Club friendly. The listings would also mention particular people to ask for, as they were known to be allies of the community.
properties.Source: Professor Noah Riseman, Australian Catholic University c/o Seahorse Victoria Shopping Guide

properties.Name: Gilmour's Shoes
properties.Story: Shoes. Featured in the 1987 Seahorse Shopping Guide, this store/service was known to be Transgender and Seahorse Club friendly. The listings would also mention particular people to ask for, as they were known to be allies of the community.
properties.Source: Professor Noah Riseman, Australian Catholic University c/o Seahorse Victoria Shopping Guide

properties.Name: Glasshouse Hotel ( 1991-2011)
properties.Story: Established by Maria Frendo, The Glasshouse was a lesbian club in Collingwood hosting popular nights such as Tuff Muff. It later rebranded itself as a queer space for all, but ran women's only nights SHEBAR on the second and fourth Saturday of each month.

properties.Name: Graceful Lingerie Salon
properties.Story: Foundation and Lingerie. Featured in the September 1980 Seahorse Shopping Guide, this store/service was known to be Transgender and Seahorse Club friendly. The listings would also mention particular people to ask for, as they were known to be allies of the community. Ask for Mrs Rogers.
properties.Source: Professor Noah Riseman, Australian Catholic University c/o Seahorse Victoria Shopping Guide

properties.Name: Greeves Street
properties.Story: This was a site where many trans sex workers worked in the 1980s-90s. During this period there was a New Zealander who very much controlled the scene and did her best to protect her girls from police.
properties.Source: Professor Noah Riseman, Australian Catholic University

properties.Name: Grouse at Bendigo Hotel
properties.Story: A popular venue with women, the Bendigo Hotel also hosted the queer indie dance party Grouse

properties.Name: Hair Happening of London
properties.Story: Hairdressers. Featured in the February 1984 Seahorse Shopping Guide, this store/service was known to be Transgender and Seahorse Club friendly. The listings would also mention particular people to ask for, as they were known to provide safe experiences for the community. Ask for Barry.
properties.Source: Professor Noah Riseman, Australian Catholic University c/o Seahorse Victoria Shopping Guide

properties.Name: Hares and Hyenas
properties.Story: Hares & Hyenas is a community institution, starting its story on Commercial Road in 1991. In the gay heyday of the 1990s, between 1993 and 1999 the business had a northside outlet, first in Fitzroy and then in Collingwood. In 1999 they consolidated their business on Commercial Road while searching for larger premises with space for events.In 2006 they moved to Johnston Street, Fitzroy, where they opened a café and a licensed performance venue, popularly known as the Harehole, which has been home to over 1500 events.

properties.Name: Heaven's Door
properties.Story: Heaven's Door was gay bar owned by Brian Frewin. It was mostly a male audience, gathering to watch drag shows and dance. But there were frequent women's nights.  Heaven's Door closed in 2012 when Frewin retired.

properties.Name: Hilliers (1970s)
properties.Story: Hilliers was a club ran by Jan Hillier of Jan's Dances.  Jan would go on to play an influential role in queer Melbourne nightlife, establishing numerous venues for the queer community and putting queer performers on map.

properties.Name: Hoochie Mama at Alia Bar
properties.Story: A Thursday night women's night, Hoochie mama had free entry and hip hop

properties.Name: House of Reneetov
properties.Story: Beauty Salon. Featured in the September 1980 and February 1984 Seahorse Shopping Guide, this store/service was known to be Transgender and Seahorse Club friendly. The listings would also mention particular people to ask for, as they were known to be allies of the community. "Ask for Pam".
properties.Source: Professor Noah Riseman, Australian Catholic University c/o Seahorse Victoria Shopping Guide

properties.Name: Imperial Hotel
properties.Story: Historically, the Melbourne pub and bar scene did not welcome women openly. For many women, in particular queer women who wanted to meet queer women, this resulted in secret lesbian bars where women would be able to drink and socialise.  The Imperial Hotel is the site of the earliest sites where Lesbians were able to gather.

properties.Name: Inaugural Australian GLBTIQ Multicultural Conference, 2004
properties.Story: St Kilda Town Hall was the venue of the first Australian GLBTIQ Multicultural Conference in October 2004. An Australian and possibly world first, the two day event welcomes over 250 people from around 30 different cultural groups for plenaries, workshops, seminars and social events. There were a dozen keynote speakers and more than 40 papers addressing all aspects of the queer multicultural experience around three themes: health and wellbeing; cultural identity and sexuality; and communities and belonging. Attendees included celebrities and representatives of the Victoria Police and the Equal Opportunity Commission, as well as the State government’s Minister for Multicultural Affairs.
properties.more than 40 papers addressing all aspec: health and wellbeing; cultural identity and sexuality; and communities and belonging. Attendees included celebrities and representatives of the Victoria Police and the Equal Opportunity Commission, as well as the State government’s Minister for Multicultu

properties.Name: Inflation
properties.Story: Inflation hosted a variety of queer nights over three levels.

properties.Name:
Initial site of the Positive Living
Centre (1993-2002)
properties.Story: Following the establishment of People Living With AIDS, a program within the Victorian AIDS Council, the Positive Living Centre was officially opened by the Mayor of St Kilda on 18 April 1993 in a celebration that involved hundreds of people, champagne and balloons. The Positive Living Centre's goal was to create a friendly place where people with HIV could drop in, chat about the latest treatments, trying to reduce some of the stigma they were feeling, some of the hopelessness they were feeling. The Centre moved to 51 Commercial Road, Prahran in 2002.

properties.Name: Irma La Douce
properties.Story: Foundation and Lingerie. Featured in the February 1984 Seahorse Shopping Guide, this store/service was known to be Transgender and Seahorse Club friendly. The listings would also mention particular people to ask for, as they were known to be allies of the community. Ask for Sophia.
properties.Source: Professor Noah Riseman, Australian Catholic University c/o Seahorse Victoria Shopping Guide

properties.Name: Jan's Dances
properties.Story: Jan's Dances were camp dance parties that toured Melbourne north and south with no set venue.  Often running in competition with Spangles (another touring queer party) they were equally as popular.  Jan's Dances were the creation of Jan Hillier,  an entrepreneur of the Melbourne lesbian and gay bar scene who would go on to play a significant role in the establishment of the venue of queer venues and fame of queer performers.

properties.Name: John Randle
properties.Story: Wig Trimming and Styling. Featured in the February 1984 Seahorse Shopping Guide, this store/service was known to be Transgender and Seahorse Club friendly. The listings would also mention particular people to ask for, as they were known to provide safe experiences for the community.
properties.Source: Professor Noah Riseman, Australian Catholic University c/o Seahorse Victoria Shopping Guide

properties.Name: Just Hair
properties.Story: Hairdressers. Featured in the September 1980 Seahorse Shopping Guide, this store/service was known to be Transgender and Seahorse Club friendly. The listings would also mention particular people to ask for, as they were known to be allies of the community. Ask for Vered Stark.
properties.Source: Professor Noah Riseman, Australian Catholic University c/o Seahorse Victoria Shopping Guide

properties.Name: Keith Haring Mural
properties.Story: On the exterior wall of the Collingwood Yards is a Keith Haring mural, one of thirty still surviving today and his only outdoor work in Australia. Haring painted the mural in 1984 during his visit to Melbourne, having been invited by ACCA director John Buckley.  The large outdoor mural can still be seen today and has been restored by Arts Victoria. Haring passed away in 1990 at the age of 34 due to AIDS related illness.

properties.Name: Kellar Bar (1973-1974)
properties.Story: Open between 1973-1974 for 9 months, the Kellar bar was reported as "Melbourne's first, exclusively camp bar" by the National Review.  One of Jan Hillier's venues, she turned an empty failing bar into one of Melbourne's most popular gay hotspots. The bar closed, when the Savoy Hotel was purchased by Victorian Government in 1974 and turned it into the Police Cadet Training Academy.  The hotel was later rebought and restored, without the gay venue.

properties.Name: Kenney Sea Baths
properties.Story: Along the beachfront of St Kilda, the Kenney family opened separate men's and women's baths. Harriet Elphinstone Dick, who ran the women's gym in the Queen Victoria Building, taught swimming here after initially arriving in Melbourne.  Renowned for her swimming abilities, Dick taught swimming to over 300 women.  She was later awarded a gold bracelet by the Governor's wife, Lady Bowen in 1978 for her work.

properties.Name: Les Girls at Bojangles Night Club
properties.Story: In what is now the St Kilda Sea Baths complex, there used to be a nightclub called Bojangles.  This was the final venue used by the Les Girls Revue in Melbourne.

properties.Name: Les Girls at Olivia's
properties.Story: After leaving the Ritz, the Les Girls revue moved to Olivia's before settling at Bojangles before it's closure.

properties.Name: Les Girls at the Ritz Hotel
properties.Story: In 1971, the Sydney Les Girls Revue arrived in Melbourne and begun their show at the Ritz Hotel.  This was the first publicised drag performance in Melbourne and as homosexuality was still illegal performers were granted permits to travel in women's clothing but not permission to be seen "on the street". Les girls would later move to the Bojangles Nightclub.

properties.Name: Lesbians and Gays for Reconciliation – Stick with Wik Banner
properties.Story: At the 1998 Midsumma Festival Pride March the Lesbians and Gays for Reconciliation raised their 'Stick with Wik' Banner, demonstrating solidarity with Indigenous Australians and particularly the Wik peoples of Queensland in their claim in the High Court of Australia for native title rights to country on the Cape York Peninsula.  Following influential events in Australia's history, such as the 1992 Mabo decision and native title, pastoral leases, and the Native Title Amendment Act of 1998, the group aimed to bring the awareness of LGBTIQ+ communities to issues facing First Nations people, to encourage recognition of the injustices of the past and to ‘create an inclusive future which recognises the benefits of cultural, racial and sexual diversity’.

properties.Name: Lesbians Are Lovely' Graffiti
properties.Address: Rae Street and St George’s Road, Fitzroy
properties.Story: Graffiti paint up protests were a common tool of the Gay Liberation and the Radicalesbians. One of the first explicitly lesbian graffiti paint ups, in two foot high letters on the corner of Rae Street and St George’s Road, Fitzroy, proclaimed that ‘Lesbians are lovely’. Lesbians continually repainted it whenever it was cleaned off, until it became an almost permanent fixture of the street.

properties.Name: Libation
properties.Story: Libation was a popular venue with lesbian crowds on a Sundays

properties.Name: Liberated Bookshop
properties.Story: Bookstores. Featured in the February 1984 Seahorse Shopping Guide, this store/service was known to be Transgender and Seahorse Club friendly. The listings would also mention particular people to ask for, as they were known to be allies of the community. “For old copies of “TRANSVESTIA” by Virginia Prince, published by Chavelier Publications. Caution: There is also a pornographic type of magazine using the same title “Transvestia”.
properties.Source: Professor Noah Riseman, Australian Catholic University c/o Seahorse Victoria Shopping Guide
properties.Caution: There is also a pornographic type of magazine using the same title “Transvestia”.

properties.Name: Liberty Belle Coffee Lounge
properties.Story: In the mid 1940s to the early 1950s, camp Melbourne flocked to the Victoria Building's Liberty Belle Coffee Lounge and adjoining City Club Hotel. Seating 50 to 60 people in booth-style seating, the Liberty Belle Coffee Lounge was a popular venue to socialise for Melbourne's queers.

properties.Name: Lillies
properties.Story: Restaurants. Featured in the 1987 Seahorse Shopping Guide, this store/service was known to be Transgender and Seahorse Club friendly. The listings would also mention particular people to ask for, as they were known to be allies of the community. "Current venue for Seahorse Victoria Dinners. Phone Stephen and Rochelle."
properties.Source: Professor Noah Riseman, Australian Catholic University c/o Seahorse Victoria Shopping Guide

properties.Name: Lincoln Institute of Health Sciences/La Trobe Voice Clinic
properties.Story: Around 1980, the Lincoln Institute began working with the Gender Dysphoria Clinic to provide speech pathology services to trans women who had undergone gender affirmation surgery. The Lincoln Institute amalgamated into La Trobe University in 1987, and they have hosted the Voice Clinic ever since.
properties.Source: Professor Noah Riseman, Australian Catholic University

properties.Name: Linda Leigh
properties.Address: Manchester Unity Building, 220 Collins St, Melbourne
properties.Story: Foundation and Lingerie. Featured in the February 1984 Seahorse Shopping Guide, this store/service was known to be Transgender and Seahorse Club friendly. The listings would also mention particular people to ask for, as they were known to be allies of the community. Ask for Rae.
properties.Source: Professor Noah Riseman, Australian Catholic University c/o Seahorse Victoria Shopping Guide

properties.Name: Lobster Pot
properties.Story: Outside the Queen Victoria Hospital for Women stood a public toilet that is thought to be the oldest beat in Melbourne.  Initially called the Lobster Pot, the beat had many names including "The Fifties and Older Bog"(due to the age of the clientele) and "The House of Jewels" (following a renovation covered in pebbles). There is no longer a public toilet at this site, having been removed in the 2000s.

properties.Name: Loose Ends
properties.Story: Fancy Dress. Featured in the 1987 Seahorse Shopping Guide, this store/service was known to be Transgender and Seahorse Club friendly. The listings would also mention particular people to ask for, as they were known to be allies of the community. "Patronised by several members since September 1984."
properties.Source: Professor Noah Riseman, Australian Catholic University c/o Seahorse Victoria Shopping Guide

properties.Name: Madgear Boutique
properties.Story: Fancy Dress. Featured in the 1987 Seahorse Shopping Guide, this store/service was known to be Transgender and Seahorse Club friendly. The listings would also mention particular people to ask for, as they were known to be allies of the community. "Patronised by several members since September 1984."
properties.Source: Professor Noah Riseman, Australian Catholic University c/o Seahorse Victoria Shopping Guide

properties.Name: Mae West's Coffee Lounge (1969-1972)
properties.Story: The Mae West Club was one of Melbourne’s first dedicated kamp-owned and operated venues. Opening in 1969, the venue was one of the first locations to offer a public venue for drag shows, the narrow venue featuring a small stage for performances. The owner and proprietor of the Mae West Club was Robert Cameron, who often performed on the small stage in drag as Giselle. Other regular performers at the club included: Cherry Ripe, Cinnamon Brown, Stan Monroe, Holly Wood, Trixie, Ruby, Doug Lucas, Jullianne Deen, and Honey West. Many of these performers were early members of Les Girls. The Mae West Club closed in early 1972, when Cameron joined Les Girls.
properties.Other regular performers at the club inc: Cherry Ripe, Cinnamon Brown, Stan Monroe, Holly Wood, Trixie, Ruby, Doug Lucas, Jullianne Deen, and Honey West. Many of these performers were early members of Les Girls. The Mae West Club closed in early 1972, when Cameron joined Les Girls.

properties.Name: Maisie's (Her Majesty’s)
properties.Story: One of the first pubs in Melbourne to welcome a queer crowd, Maisie's opened in the 1960s.  Named after its owner, Ron Philp (who was nicknamed Maisie) it became a popular venue in Melbourne's south.

properties.Name: Mandate (1980-1989)
properties.Story: Formerly the site of Sweethearts (1979 -1980), Ken Payne's Mandate opened in 1980 and was Melbourne's first exclusively gay disco following the legalisation of homosexuality. Most nights of the week Mandate was a men's venue, but Tuesday nights was a women's night called Club 31, which was hosted by Neggie and Sally.

properties.Name: Marriage Equality Victoria
properties.Address: Victorian Trades Hall Council, 54 Victoria St, Carlton VIC 3053
properties.Story: The Trades hall was the homebase of 2016 Marriage Equality Campaign and the location of the celebratory street party after marriage equality was approved by plebiscite. The union movement had been an invested supporter of marriage equality and equal rights for their workers. Australian unions played a vital role in the fight against HIV/AIDS, with the nurses’ union taking the lead in educating its members, the hospital workforce and patients, as well as lobbying governments and the medical profession to take action. Tramways union members made panels for the Australian AIDS Memorial Quilt Project in honour of their workmates and Trades Hall offered a room – which became known as the Quilt Room – where people could gather to make quilt panels for their loved ones.

properties.Name: Melbourne Church of England Girls Grammar
properties.Story: Dorothy Ross was the headmistress of the Melbourne Church of England Girls Grammar from the 1930s to the 1950s.  During her time as headmistress Ross, a lesbian, promoted her partner Mary Davis to the role of Headmistress of the Junior School, despite her young age and lack of experience. Despite this she remained at the school without issue.

properties.Name: Melbourne's first women's only gym (1881)
properties.Story: In what was once the Queen Victoria Building, Miss Harriet Dick opened Melbourne's first women's only gym in the early 1881.  A swimming champion with a strong focus on physical fitness, Dick ran the gym for 20 years.  Miss Dick lived in Brighton with her female partner and they also owned a farm in Clayton where they had only female animals.

properties.Name: Middle Park Clinic
properties.Story: Medical Practioners. Featured in the February 1984 Seahorse Shopping Guide, this store/service was known to be Transgender and Seahorse Club friendly. The listings would also mention particular people to ask for, as they were known to provide safe experiences for the community.
properties.Source: Professor Noah Riseman, Australian Catholic University c/o Seahorse Victoria Shopping Guide

properties.Name: Midsumma Carnival
properties.Address: Alexandra Gardens Skate Park, 3 Boathouse Dr, Melbourne VIC 3004
properties.Story: Carnival Day was first held at Alexandra Gardens in 1995 and has now grown into an established and consistent celebration of Melbourne’s LGBTIQ+ arts and culture. Thousands of LGBTIQ+ people from across Melbourne make their way to the gardens each summer for the annual Midsumma Carnival, to join with community and celebrate the start of the Midsumma Festival. It’s an opportunity to connect with friends and engage with the social, political, lifestyle, sporting, and community groups that set up stalls for the duration of the day. Stallholders and groups as diverse as Gays and Lesbians Against Discrimination, the Prostitutes Collective, Positive Women, Rainbow Families, Greek & Gay Network, Jewish Lesbian Group of Victoria and the Multicultural Gay Group have all participated over the years. It also hosts events such as the annual dog show.

properties.Name: Milady Fashion Shoes
properties.Story: Shoes. Featured in the February 1984 Seahorse Shopping Guide, this store/service was known to be Transgender and Seahorse Club friendly. The listings would also mention particular people to ask for, as they were known to provide safe experiences for the community.
properties.Source: Professor Noah Riseman, Australian Catholic University c/o Seahorse Victoria Shopping Guide

properties.Name: MQFF at the Treasury Theatre (1990)
properties.Address: Lower Plaza, 1 Macarthur St, Melbourne VIC 3000
properties.Story: Treasury Theatre was the initial site for the screenings of the Melbourne Queer Film Festival

properties.Name: Murder of John Sacco (1985)
properties.Address: Footscray Park, 40 Maribyrnong Blvd, Footscray VIC 3011
properties.Story: John Sacco (55) was a newly out gay man. Having had a wife and children previously, Sacco had recently left his family and accepted his homosexuality.  On December 21, John Sacco was murdered by Robert Hughes (35), who shot and robbed him.  Sacco crawled for 20 metres after the attack but was not found till the next morning.  His murderer was charged in 1986.

properties.Name: Myer Melbourne
properties.Story: Wigs. Featured in the February 1984 Seahorse Shopping Guide, this store/service was known to be Transgender and Seahorse Club friendly. The listings would also mention particular people to ask for, as they were known to provide safe experiences for the community.
properties.Source: Professor Noah Riseman, Australian Catholic University c/o Seahorse Victoria Shopping Guide

properties.Name: Myer Melbourne (Late 1950s - early 1960s)
properties.Story: In the late 50s to early 60s, Melbourne queers would flock to Myer Melbourne for work. At the time, Freddie Asmussen was the Head of the Display Department and was responsible for the outlandish window displays that still live on today. Freddie was known in the queer circles as an "outrageous queen", filling Myer with young, attractive and creative men who were labelled "Freddie's boys". He was also known to have starring roles in the Art's Balls of the 60s at the Palais De Danse. Fred Asmussen designed every Myer Christmas display until he passed away in 1974, his contribution to the Melbourne queer scene undeniably brought creativity, energy and excitement.

properties.Name: Neverwhere
properties.Story: Neverwhere was a northside queer venue hosting drag queens and kings.

properties.Name: Newmarket Hotel
properties.Story: The Newmarket hotel became the home of Tootsie and a group of drag queens following their departure from the Greyhound.  When the Greyhound later closed, the Newmarket became gay on Saturdays, attempting to create a new home for the crowds heartbroken by the GH's closure.

properties.Name: Open Leaves Bookshop
properties.Story: Bookstores. Featured in the February 1984 Seahorse Shopping Guide, this store/service was known to be Transgender and Seahorse Club friendly. The listings would also mention particular people to ask for, as they were known to be allies of the community. "Books on TV’s and TS’s”.
properties.Source: Professor Noah Riseman, Australian Catholic University c/o Seahorse Victoria Shopping Guide

properties.Name: Opium Den
properties.Story: The Opium Den was a mixed venue, hosting separate women's and men's nights.  It featured drag shows, both kings and queens, and was a popular venue with Melbourne's queer Asian community. Along with being a club, the venue was also a hotel.

properties.Name: Our Glad and Elise Wilson
properties.Story: Gladys Moncrieff was a famous Melbourne singer and actress, often called "Our Glad".  She was a popular performer through the 20s and 30s and had a fanbase called the 'Gallery Girls' who would follow her to every show.  One of the Gallery Girls, Elsie Wilson, would later become a romantic partner of Gladys.  In 1968 the two "companions" moved to Queensland to retire. Although their relationship was never publicly stated, it is clear that they were indeed queer.

properties.Name: Out Video
properties.Story: A Gay and Lesbian specialist DVD and video store, Out Video allowed hire and purchaseof a range of queer and queer related films. They also offered a mail order service.

properties.Name: Paddy Paton
properties.Story: Dressmakers. Featured in the February 1984 Seahorse Shopping Guide, this store/service was known to be Transgender and Seahorse Club friendly. The listings would also mention particular people to ask for, as they were known to be allies of the community.
properties.Source: Professor Noah Riseman, Australian Catholic University c/o Seahorse Victoria Shopping Guide

properties.Name: Paint N Powder
properties.Story: Perfumes and Cosmetics. Featured in the February 1984 Seahorse Shopping Guide, this store/service was known to be Transgender and Seahorse Club friendly. The listings would also mention particular people to ask for, as they were known to provide safe experiences for the community.
properties.Source: Professor Noah Riseman, Australian Catholic University c/o Seahorse Victoria Shopping Guide

properties.Name: Palais De Danse - Arts Balls (1920-1980)
properties.Story: The Arts Balls of the 1960s started out as an homage to the Parisian balls of the 1920s, organised by art students wanting a place to hone their creativity. These Arts Balls were amongst the limited public places where campy queerness reigned, with drag queens often being the star of the show. Amongst those who frequented was in infamous drag queen Lottie (Robert Lotte) known for her ball costumes and Freddie Asmussen performing tableu's dressed as Louis XIV and Cleopatra.

properties.Name: Pentridge Prison
properties.Story: Pentridge Prison became the temporary living situation for many members of the queer community, particularly for queer men who were caught during, accused of or suspected to be engaging in homosexual behaviours and drag. Although the cases brought against these men were not always true, simply being a homosexual male was a crime. With great homophobia in the police force, there were many sting operations (such as at Black Rock Beach) to trap queer men through undercover means. Noel Tovey, a high-profile Indigenous dancer, was held here after being charged for buggery. He was initially arrested in 1951 at the home of Max du Barry, an infamous female impersonator, after a police raid. Police allegedly beat Tovey, who was just 17, until he was forced to confess to having sex with du Barry. Both were charged and convicted.
properties.Source: Human Rights Law Centre 'Righting historical wrongs' - https://static1.squarespace.com/static/580025f66b8f5b2dabbe4291/t/5823b6c659cc6829f22afdb0/1478735601892/Gay_Sex_Convictions_Paper_January2014.pdf

properties.Name: Police Targeting Homosexual Men (1976-1977)
properties.Story: Over the summer of 1976 and 1977, 100 men were arrested around Black Rock Beach for "loitering with homosexual intent". The police intentionally trapped men, suspected to be homosexual, by having young police officers attend the beach in speedos and actively start conversations with them on the beach.  Homosexuality was still illegal at this time, so even alluding to being homosexual or being involved in homosexual acts could result in arrest.  Many of the men were arrested after simply stating they were gay, following questions from the undercover police officers.  These arrests became highly critiqued in the media and wider community, becoming a platform for the Homosexual Law Reform Coalition to garner support from the public for the decriminalisation of homosexual sex between men.

properties.Name: POOF DOOF @ Chasers
properties.Story: Chasers has played host to a variety of queer events, but most notably it has become the home of POOF DOOF since its move from The Bottom End

properties.Name: Positive Living Centre (2002 - )
properties.Story: The Positive Living Centre enhances the health and well-being of HIV positive people, through the provision of social, emotional, recreational, and skills-based services and activities. It is emblematic of Australian community led responses to HIV/AIDS. The name for the Positive Living Centre was chosen as a deliberate play on words to counter the stigmatising image of people living with AIDS as victims. The centre plays a vital role in the lives of HIV positive people. Staff and volunteers work on policy, education and advocacy around HIV/AIDS, and the centre provides counselling services, food deliveries and other welfare services to those in need, as well as spaces for therapy groups to meet.

properties.Name: Precinct 3182 - The Duke
properties.Address: 374 St Kilda Rd, corner Martin Street, St Kilda
properties.Story: Opening as the Duke in 1998 as part of the ambitious Precinct 3182 area, the Duke was a male only bar.  Developed by a group of gay business men, including Ken Payne, the area housed a bar, cinema, night club and sauna.  Following the closure of the nightclub and sauna, Duke remained a gay venue for couple years before closing its doors.

properties.Name: Precinct 3182 - The Laneway Club
properties.Story: The Laneway Club opened as part of the ambitious Precinct 3182 area, developed by a group of gay business men, including Ken Payne.  The venue featured a variety of public transport vehicles in its interior.

properties.Name: Precinct 3182 - The Laneway Sauna
properties.Story: Laneway Sauna opened as part of the ambitious Precinct 3182 area, developed by a group of gay business men, including Ken Payne. The sauna included a gym which had to obtain a special exemption from the Equal Opportunity Commission to make the site men only. The sauna featured a black maze as well as themed rooms for hire, with access to seven channels for porn.

properties.Name: Pride March
properties.Story: Established in 1996, Pride March Victoria has paraded down Fitzroy Street demonstrating the diversity of the queer community and increasing representation.  The first Pride March attracted 11,000 people including high school kids, drag queens and community organisations, who marched down Fitzroy Street together in celebration.

properties.Name: Prince of Wales Hotel (1930- )
properties.Story: The Prince of Wales is possibly the oldest gay bar in Melbourne, allegedly being a queer space from the 1930s.  In the 70s it was host of Melbourne's first Lesbian disco Pennies.  Pennies was produced by Jan Hillier and ran on Saturdays. Later Hillier would approach the POW to do a drag night on Sundays called Pokeys.  Pokeys (1977-1992) was an elaborate Sunday night drag show at the Prince of Wales Hotel in St Kilda.  It was co-run by Doug Lucas and gay nightlife icon Jan Hillier. It was one of Melbourne's most popular drag nights, reaching more than a thousand people in the audience. The shows included notable names such as "The Fab Four" Rene Scott, Debra Le Gae, Terry Tinsel  and Michelle Tozer, as well as Vivian St. James, Jacque Roberts, Amanda Lee Linsley, Caralie De Winter and Sheree La More.  The first HIV/AIDS fundraisers in Victoria occurred at Pokeys. This included an event to raise money for the HIV/AIDS ward at Fairfield Hospital, with patron guests Don Dunstan and Ita Buttrose. Another Pokeys fundraiser helped to establish support for women living with HIV in Victoria. Pokeys ended in 1992, following the selling of the venue to new owners.  It has remained a LGBTQI friendly location.

properties.Name: Priscilla's@153
properties.Story: Priscilla's was a small venue that hosted drag performances, open from Wednesday to Saturday.

properties.Name: Protest for Mike Clohessy
properties.Story: Following his 1975 appearance on television to discuss the Royal Commission on Human Relationships and treatment of homosexuality, Mike Clohessy was fired from his role as a teacher.  Clohessy was a queer man and once publicly outed by his TV apperance the Catholic Education Office in Sydney immediately dismissed him from his role.  Standing up for Clohessy, the Gay Liberation movement drafted a letter and had it signed by half a dozen activist groups.  This lead to a demonstration at St Francis' Church when the Catholic Education Office would not reinstate Clohessy or answer their calls for a reason for his dismissal. This protest lead to further protests in Geelong and the generation of the Geelong Gay Liberation movement.

properties.Name: Prue Gibson
properties.Story: Electrolysis. Featured in the February 1984 Seahorse Shopping Guide, this store/service was known to be Transgender and Seahorse Club friendly. The listings would also mention particular people to ask for, as they were known to be allies of the community.
properties.Source: Professor Noah Riseman, Australian Catholic University c/o Seahorse Victoria Shopping Guide

properties.Name: Public Beat
properties.Story: In 1901, a number of locations were reported to the Chief Commissioner Of Police in Melbourne as a beat by a concerned resident called Mr B. Cleal. At this location stood the Old City Court, which at its rear was known as meeting place for queer men.  The Old City Court was later demolished.

properties.Name: Public Beat
properties.Story: In 1901, a number of locations were reported to the Chief Commissioner Of Police in Melbourne as a beat by a concerned resident called Mr B. Cleal. Queer men would meet under the Flinders Street Railway Viaduct opposite Customs House (now the Immigration Museum).

properties.Name: Public Beat
properties.Address: SEA LIFE Melbourne Aquarium, King St, Melbourne VIC 3000
properties.Story: In 1901, a number of locations were reported to the Chief Commissioner Of Police in Melbourne as a beat by a concerned resident called Mr B. Cleal. Queer men would meet under the Flinders Street Railway Viaduct at the base of King Street.

properties.Name: Public Toilet Beat
properties.Address: Victoria St & Rathdowne St, Carlton VIC 3053
properties.Story: In 1901, a number of public toilets were reported to the Chief Commissioner Of Police in Melbourne as a beat by a concerned resident called Mr B. Cleal.

properties.Name: Public Toilet Beat
properties.Story: In 1901, a number of public toilets were reported to the Chief Commissioner Of Police in Melbourne as a beat by a concerned resident called Mr B. Cleal.

properties.Name: Public Toilet Beat
properties.Story: On what was formerly Napier Street was a men's public bathroom.  Known as beat frequented by queer men and drug users, the toilet was covered in the 1970s and remains buried, fully intact, underground.

properties.Name: Public Toilet Beat
properties.Story: The site of a public toilet beat before its many conversions.

properties.Name: Queen Victoria Hospital for Women
properties.Story: One of the first hospitals in Melbourne to specialise in gender confirming surgery.

properties.Name: Queer Marriages officiated at Saint Francis’ Church
properties.Story: Saint Francis' has officiated Australia's first queer Catholic marriages. Ellen Tremaye (an Irish settler who on arrival to Australia in 1856, went by the name Edward de Lacy Evans) married Mary Delahunty, their bunkmate on the Ocean Monarch. de Lacy Evans is considered one of Australia's first documented transgender people. de Lacy Evans lived as a man for twenty two years, marrying twice more, before having their biological gender revealed when they were admitted to Kew Asylum in 1879. There was a lot of publicity about their identity (including the 1880 book "The Man-Woman") and after being released they began working in a travelling carnival as an attraction. After this time they moved to Melbourne, where they spent the rest of their life living in a poorhouse as Mrs de Lacy Evans. de Lacy Evans passed away in 1901. A century later, St Francis Church also officiated the wedding of Bill Edwards (born Marion Edwards) and his wife Lucy Minehan.  Bill had lived as a man from the age of 13 and was known to be quite a ladies man. His birth gender was only revealed following an arrest for burglary and his escape to Brisbane after skipping bail. This drew great attention in Brisbane and Melbourne, being reported in newspapers at the time. In contrast to de Lacy Evans, Bill continued his life living as a man until he passed away in 1956.
properties.Source: https://www.emelbourne.net.au/biogs/EM00446b.htm Lucy Chesser, "Australasian Lesbian Movement, ‘Claudia’s Group’ and Lynx: ‘Non-Political Lesbian Organisation in Melbourne, 1969-1980”, Hecate: An Interdisciplinary Journal of Women's Liberation, vol. 22, no. 1, 1996, pp. 69–91. http://alga.org.au/files/history-walk/2011-History-Walk-program.pdf

properties.Name: Queer protest against racism
properties.Address: Fawkner Railway Station, Sydney Rd, Hadfield VIC 3046
properties.Story: On the 15th of March, 1997, Gays and Lesbians Against Racism (GLAR)(which had formed one month prior in response to the racist violence and debate generated by Pauline Hanson), Queer Action, the Jewish Lesbian Group of Victoria, and another twenty local groups gathered in Fawkner Park to protest rising racism. Four hundred protesters removed racist graffiti from shops and the Fawkner Railway Station, then marched on a shop in Tyson Street operated by the right-wing National Action. Four protesters were arrested after violent clashes between protesters, National Action supporters and Victoria Police. Accounts of the day can be heard in the Jewish Lesbian Group of Victoria's film 'Its Who We Are'

properties.Name: Radicalesbians Group (1973)
properties.Story: Formed by Jenny Pausaker and inspired by radical feminist theory, Radicalesbians rejected the sexism and power dynamic men brought to the Gay Liberation movement. At the time lesbians were discriminated against by those in the Melbourne Gay Liberation and Women's Lib Movement, creating a difficult decision for gay women to decide between the three groups and whether to withdraw politically and socially from men overall.

properties.Name: Raffles Cafe
properties.Story: In the basement level of what is now Collins 234 was Raffles Cafe, an affordable and friendly cafe for Melbourne queers in the 1940s and 1950s.

properties.Name: Raw Hide (1982) and Red Raw Parties
properties.Address:
Little Grey St
St Kilda VIC 3182
properties.Story: In Decmeber 1982, a warehouse located on Little Grey Street, ALSO threw their first dance party called Raw Hide. Attended by over 700 men dressed as cowboys, the party was so good that Raw Hide would go on to become an annual event.  In 1984, ALSO partnered with the Victorian AIDS Council to host a second dance party called Winter Daze during the Queen's Birthday Long Weekend.  Both events would continue for many years - Raw Hide becoming Red Raw. Despite the success, the organisation of such parties was greatly affected by the HIV and AIDS related deaths of the creative people involved.  Red Raw continued until 2007 and ALSO disbanded in 2010. These parties not only were not only important events in the queer calendar but great employers of queer people, the heterosexual party world not wanting to be associated with a queer crowd.  ALSO's parties also informed the future of Melbourne's dance party and rave scene, being a case study for heterosexual and queer promoters on how to do it right.

properties.Name: Roni's Body Boutique
properties.Address: Shop 40, The Hub, Langhorne St, Dandenong
properties.Story: Foundation and Lingerie. Featured in the September 1980 Seahorse Shopping Guide, this store/service was known to be Transgender and Seahorse Club friendly. The listings would also mention particular people to ask for, as they were known to be allies of the community.
properties.Source: Professor Noah Riseman, Australian Catholic University c/o Seahorse Victoria Shopping Guide

properties.Name: Royal Turkish Baths (1870-1929)
properties.Address: Royal Arcade Bourke Street, Melbourne, VIC 3000
properties.Story: The Royal Arcade housed the Royal Turkish Baths between 1870 and 1929.  Although there is no recorded evidence (in the form of arrests, as homosexuality was a crime at the time), the baths are said to be an early meeting place for secret queer experiences, similar to the saunas and bathhouses we know today.

properties.Name: Salon Kitty
properties.Story: The birthplace of King Victoria, a Drag King show by Bumperbar and Tom Erge, Salon Kitty is an important venue in Melbourne's Drag King Scene. Despite little advertising, the first King Victoria night, in May 2000, drew 10 performers and a crowd of 500.

properties.Name: Seahorse Victoria
properties.Address: Lansdowne Road, East St Kilda, Victoria
properties.Story: The inaugural meeting of Seahorse Victoria was held in a flat here in September 1975. The original membership list was twelve people, but that very quickly grew and it continues to be the oldest trans group in Victoria.
properties.Source: Professor Noah Riseman, Australian Catholic University

properties.Name: Shortest lived Radicalesbian graffiti
properties.Story: Site of the shortest lived graffiti paint ups by the Radicalesbians, whatever was written implied that the Nuns living in the convent were lesbians.  The graffiti was painted at night and was removed by the next morning.

properties.Name: Showtime
properties.Story: Fancy Dress. Featured in the 1987 Seahorse Shopping Guide, this store/service was known to be Transgender and Seahorse Club friendly. The listings would also mention particular people to ask for, as they were known to be allies of the community. "Patronised by several members since September 1984."
properties.Source: Professor Noah Riseman, Australian Catholic University c/o Seahorse Victoria Shopping Guide

properties.Name: Shrew Women’s Bookshop (1983-1997)
properties.Story: Considered Melbourne’s first feminist bookshop, Shrew Women’s Bookshop sold books ‘for and about women'.  A busy space, the bookshop held events, were active on 3CR radio and sold tickets to women’s events across Melbourne.

properties.Name: Single Sex Balls (1908)
properties.Story: Held in what was the Federal Hall, single sex balls were an opportunity for people to explore dressing in drag. The women's balls were seen as a source of entertainment and fun, just women playing dress up. This was not the case for the one men's only ball, and considering the response to men in drag documented through arrests such as that of Alan McKail (20) Douglas Ogilvie (22) and Tom Page (25) in the same year, it is no surprise there was never a second ball.

properties.Name: Sir Charles Hotham Hotel
properties.Story: The Sir Charles Hotham Hotel is a four-storey Art Nouveau building that's upstairs bar provided a venue for drag shows and singalongs on Saturday nights in the 1950s and 1960s. The shows were performed on a stage made of two dining room tables pushed together in front of a bay window. There was an upright piano on each side, and costumes were improvised from whatever was at hand. The crowd was mixed. Kamp men and their friends would queue to get in, and the downstairs working-class male clientele would sometimes come upstairs and join in. The stories around the Sir Charles Hotham Hotel reflect a queer world that flourished just outside of respectable middle-class society’s field of vision.

properties.Name: Sircuit
properties.Story: This location has had many different iterations. Once called Mayfields, it was an OutBlack venue for a number of years after The Star Hotel was deemed too small to accommodate the growing number of people who attended OutBlack events. Mayfields is now named Sircuit and is a bar with drag performers and space to dance.  The venue used to have a cruising lounge upstairs, which has closed and has been covered to the drag bar Mollies. Sircuit also hosts ADAM, a ticketed nude social night some nights of the week.

properties.Name: Sixteen of South Yarra
properties.Story: Dresses and Gowns. Featured in the September 1980 Seahorse Shopping Guide, this store/service was known to be Transgender and Seahorse Club friendly. The listings would also mention particular people to ask for, as they were known to be allies of the community. Ask for Daani.
properties.Source: Professor Noah Riseman, Australian Catholic University c/o Seahorse Victoria Shopping Guide

properties.Name: Skorus Books
properties.Story: During the 70s, Skorus books was one of the early home of the Daughters of Billitis', Melbourne's first camp political organisation. The Australian chapter of the DOB was formed in Melbourne in 1969, making it Australia's first gay rights group. Originally formed in San Fransisco in 1955, the DOB was the first lesbian and political rights organisation in the US. The name 'Bilitis' was decided as it is the name of a fictional lover of Sappho, who lived on the Isle of Lesbos alongside her. It was created as an alternative to lesbian bars to avoid police harassment and raids as it was illegal to dance with the same sex in public at the time. The DOB focused on educating members about their rights and provided support for those coming out. Eventually the Melbourne branch rejected their the radicalisation of their American counterpart, renaming themselves as the Australiasian Lesbian Movement.

properties.Name: Slim-It Corset Salon
properties.Story: Foundation and Lingerie. Featured in the February 1984 Seahorse Shopping Guide, this store/service was known to be Transgender and Seahorse Club friendly. The listings would also mention particular people to ask for, as they were known to be allies of the community. Ask for Rose.
properties.Source: Professor Noah Riseman, Australian Catholic University c/o Seahorse Victoria Shopping Guide

properties.Name: Snowden Gardens
properties.Story: Before the site was Hamer Hall, the Snowden Gardens was located here. The Snowden Gardens was a popular cruising area from the 1920s.

properties.Name: Society Five Meeting Place
properties.Story: One of meeting places of gay rights lobby group Society Five

properties.Name: Spangles
properties.Story: Spangles was a weekly dance party on Friday nights in the 70s.  Entry required membership and a $2.50 entrance fee but allowed guests to party till 2 or 2.30am.  The party moved constantly between venues but began here at the church hall of what is now Christ Church Grammar School. Once the church discovered what type of event they had been hosting, the party had to move on and Spangles began to jump around the city, north and south side.  It was a popular event with all of the queer and heterosexual community.

properties.Name: St Mark’s Anglican Church
properties.Story:
St Mark’s Anglican Church has a strong history of providing social welfare support and facilities for the local community. The church holds important meaning for its longstanding mission to support LGBTIQ+ people, especially during the AIDS crisis.
