In 1980 St Mark’s appointed a social worker, Peter Burke, to run emergency relief and a community lounge. From there, the church began a more active collaboration with its surrounding communities. It hired out its hall to gay groups for meetings at a time when many organisations found that idea objectionable or too controversial. A fundraiser for Gay Community News was hosted there in May 1980, nearly a year before decriminalisation was implemented in Victoria. Beginning in the mid-1980s, St Mark’s ran an AIDS ministry, offering pastoral services and advocacy for people living with HIV and AIDS. Its annual AIDS requiem, held from 1986 and throughout the 1990s, was an important event for many people living with AIDS, drawing crowds of about 500 at its peak.
A new phase began in 2012 when the first Midsumma Mass was held at St Mark’s. Commencing in 1996. In 2014, St Mark’s vicar Father Stuart Soley delivered an apology to LGBTIQ+ communities. The church’s steeple was lit up in the colour purple as a symbol of apology to LGBTIQ+ communities and to people with HIV/AIDS who have also been subjected to the same ill- informed stigmatisation by the church. The steeple remained lit up for the duration of the 20th International AIDS Conference, which was held in Melbourne that year.

properties.Name: St Peter’s Eastern Hill
properties.Story: St Peter’s Eastern Hill Anglican Church is important to LGBTIQ+ communities for its longstanding welcoming and supportive stance. Although not public activists in support for LGBTIQ+ people has a history of a strong commitment to social justice. The vicar at St Peter’s from 1926 to 1964 was Farnham Maynard, who made clear his thoughts about homosexuality in his papers. Maynard wrote of homosexuality as ‘this trouble’, arguing that homosexuals were ‘God’s children too and not at all responsible for their condition’. Society’s attitude, he thought, was ‘rather unfair’.

properties.Name: Steamworks (1980-2008)
properties.Story: On the 1st of August 1980, Steamworks had their grand opening.  Established by Cyril Stokes, Steamworks was one of the largest and longest running saunas in Melbourne. There was great collaboration with the Melbourne Communicable Disease Centre, with regular lectures on sexual health, weekly blood tests for syphilis and HIV from early 1981 until the sauna closed in 2008. Steamworks was a large promoter of safe sex, providing condoms and lube throughout and after the HIV/AIDS epidemic.

properties.Name: Stiffies at Melbourne General Cemetery
properties.Story: Inside the East Gate of the Melbourne General Cemetery at the Mens Public Toilets was a beat affectionately called "Stiffies".

properties.Name: Subway Sauna
properties.Story: Subway is the only sauna in the CBD.  It has a cruising maze, porn lounges, spa, steam room and sauna.

properties.Name: Sue's Hairdressing
properties.Story: Hairdressers. Featured in the February 1984 Seahorse Shopping Guide, this store/service was known to be Transgender and Seahorse Club friendly. The listings would also mention particular people to ask for, as they were known to provide safe experiences for the community. “At Knoxfield or in your own home. Have you hair styled femme for that special occasion. Come femme if you wish. Ask for Sue.”
properties.Source: Professor Noah Riseman, Australian Catholic University c/o Seahorse Victoria Shopping Guide

properties.Name: Swamp Upstairs
properties.Story: Dresses and Gowns. Featured in the February 1984 Seahorse Shopping Guide, this store/service was known to be Transgender and Seahorse Club friendly. The listings would also mention particular people to ask for, as they were known to be allies of the community.
properties.Source: Professor Noah Riseman, Australian Catholic University c/o Seahorse Victoria Shopping Guide

properties.Name: Sybylla Press and Correct Line Graphics
properties.Story: 193 Smith Street was ground floor home of Sybylla Press and first floor home of Correct Line Graphics during the early 1980s. Sybylla Press was a feminist printer launched in 1976 by a collective of women committed to providing print services for women’s organisations and other political and community groups. In 1982 they were able to move in publishing due to a Victorian Government's Community Development Program.  This allowed the organisation to publish it's first book Frictions, a collection of feminist writings. Sybylla Press continued printing until 1988 and were publishing until 2001. Correct Line Graphics (CLG) began in 1980 as a front for the production of Gay Community News. CLG allowed the organisation to also recieve frunding through the CDP, allowing them to rent the space at 193 Smith Street. CLG continued to release issues of Gay Community News, later named OutRage, until 2000.

properties.Name: Taiping Cafe (1930s)
properties.Story: Known as a late night coffee shop frequented by gay men and lesbians.

properties.Name: Tait's Coffee Lounge (1930s)
properties.Story: In the basement of the Manchester Unity Building was Tait's, a 200 seat venue that – although not a queer venue – was frequented by many members of the queer community after a night at the movies in the 1930s.

properties.Name: Tasty Nightclub Raid (1994)
properties.Story: In the last hours of the 6th and the start of the 7th of August 1994, Victoria Police raided the Tasty Club, a queer night at the Commerce Club. All 463 patrons and staff were held for seven hours, publicly strip and cavity searched for drugs, leading to two arrests for minor drug charges, which were later dropped. The incident gained great publicity in queer and heterosexual circles as well as criticism for Victoria Police's continued homophobic attitude. Victorian Premier Jeff Kennett stated how disturbed he was the the raid. Melbourne lawyer Gary Singer, who had been in attendance, launched a class action lawsuit against Victoria Police and successfully received compensation for over 240 individuals on the grounds of false imprisonment and assault.

properties.Name: Tem Pty. Ltd.
properties.Story: Perfumes and Cosmetics. Featured in the February 1984 Seahorse Shopping Guide, this store/service was known to be Transgender and Seahorse Club friendly. The listings would also mention particular people to ask for, as they were known to provide safe experiences for the community.
properties.Source: Professor Noah Riseman, Australian Catholic University c/o Seahorse Victoria Shopping Guide

properties.Name: The Anglers Club (1981- 1986)
properties.Story: The Anglers Club was host to a variety of queer events.

properties.Name: The Beaconsfield Hotel (1990s)
properties.Address: 341 Beaconsfield Parade, corner Cowderoy Street, St Kilda
properties.Story: The Beaconsfield Hotel was a gay pub in the 90s.

properties.Name: The Boilers at the Royal Arcade Hotel (1959)
properties.Story: Royal Arcade Hotel was the first meeting place of  The Boilers, believed to be the oldest gay club operating in Australia. The initial meeting took place in 1959 and The Boilers are still running today. The Hotel was later demolished and replaced by Australia-on-Collins.

properties.Name: The Bottom End
properties.Story: At one point playing host to Poof Doof on Saturdays, initially welcoming guests through the front entrance before switching to the back, The Bottom End continues to host a monthly gay RnB night called Swagger.

properties.Name: The Bowery Theatre
properties.Story:
In 2017, the legacy of Leigh Bowery was recognised by the City of Brimbank in the naming of their new theatre complex The Bowery. Bowery was born in Sunshine in 1961, later attending Melbourne Boys’ High School and went on to study fashion and textiles at the Royal Melbourne Institute of Technology (RMIT). In 1980, at the age of 19 and bored with life in Melbourne, he left for London with a ‘suitcase and his sewing machine’. While there, he set about creating the flamboyant, garish persona he became known for as he revelled in the 1980s London underground and New Romantic club scene. Bowery is known for his iconic sculptural forms that explored and pushed the boundaries of traditional drag and camp to the extreme. His design influences can be seen in the works of Alexander McQueen, Vivienne Westwood and Gareth Pugh.
Bowery’s creations are now held in museum collections throughout the world and have featured at the 51st Venice Biennale, Victoria and Albert Museum, Museum of Contemporary Art and the National Gallery of Victoria.
Bowery died of AIDS in 1994 at the age of 34. Lucian Freud paid for his body to be flown back to his family in Victoria, where he is buried alongside his mother at the Macedon Cemetery.

properties.Name: The Bra Shop
properties.Story: Foundation and Lingerie. Featured in the February 1984 Seahorse Shopping Guide, this store/service was known to be Transgender and Seahorse Club friendly. The listings would also mention particular people to ask for, as they were known to be allies of the community. “Ask for Brian or David who will arrange a suitable occasion for selection and buying. Breast Prothesis also available.”
properties.Source: Professor Noah Riseman, Australian Catholic University c/o Seahorse Victoria Shopping Guide

properties.Name: The Bra Shop
properties.Story: Foundation and Lingerie. Featured in the September 1980 Seahorse Shopping Guide, this store/service was known to be Transgender and Seahorse Club friendly. The listings would also mention particular people to ask for, as they were known to be allies of the community. “Ask for Brian or David who will arrange a suitable occasion for selection and buying. Discount for Seahorse members. Breast Prothesis also available.”
properties.Source: Professor Noah Riseman, Australian Catholic University c/o Seahorse Victoria Shopping Guide

properties.Name: The Builders Arms Hotel
properties.Story: The Builders Arms Hotel is a landmark to the indigenous community of Melbourne, as commemorated on an exterior historical marker. The venue is also a landmark to the queer community, hosting various OutBlack events and in 1996 became the home of Q+A (Queer and Alternative). It was one of Melbourne's first LGBTIQ nights in the 1990s - a time when the community wasn't as open. Q+A would call the Builder's Arms home until 2005.

properties.Name: The Chicken Run
properties.Story: The path along the St Kilda Rd in the Botanic Gardens was a popular cruising area from the 1920s nicknamed "The Chicken Run"

properties.Name: The Club
properties.Story: Somewhere along Collins street, between Queen and Elizabeth was The Club.  The Club was a queer male venue on Saturday and Sunday nights in the mid 1930s.  Alcohol sales were prohibited at the time, but this did not stop The Club, who also had a BYO alcohol policy. The Club also had a BYO drag policy, offering change rooms that allowed customers to swap in and out of their outfits.

properties.Name: The Confessional
properties.Story: During World War 2, St Paul's converted the Chapter House into a recreation club and canteen for enlisted men. The toilets of Chapter House quickly became a beat known as "The Confessional"

properties.Name: The Continental Baths
properties.Address: Centreway Arcade, Collins St, Melbourne VIC 3000
properties.Story: The Continental Baths was a sauna that sat opposite the Australia Hotel in the basement level of the Centreway Arcade in Collins Street. This became a handy location for the gays frequenting the Woolshed as it was a convenient place for hookups in the CBD.

properties.Name: The Cuddly Flirt
properties.Address: Pran Central, Cnr of Commerical Rd and Chapel St
properties.Story: Dresses and Gowns. Featured in the September 1980 Seahorse Shopping Guide, this store/service was known to be Transgender and Seahorse Club friendly. The listings would also mention particular people to ask for, as they were known to be allies of the community. "Ask for Glenda Craig about special times for Seahorse Members"
properties.Source: Professor Noah Riseman, Australian Catholic University c/o Seahorse Victoria Shopping Guide

properties.Name: The Great Petition
properties.Story: The Great Petition is a twenty-metre steel and bluestone sculpture designed by Susan Hewitt and Penelope Lee, located in Melbourne’s Burston Reserve near the Victorian State Parliament. It celebrates the 1891 Women’s Suffrage Petition and the hard-fought struggle for women’s right to vote in Victoria. One of the signatories of the petition which is memorialised by the sculpture was Mary Fullerton. Fullerton was active in the women’s rights movement, advocating for the vote, marriage and divorce equality, and inheritance rights. In 1910, while campaigning to have prominent feminist and suffragist Vida Goldstein elected to the State parliament, Fullerton met Mabel Singleton. They soon became friends, and the relationship grew more intimate. They lived together, raising Singleton’s son, from 1922 until Fullerton’s death in 1946. Fullerton wrote 100 poems reflecting on the relationship and her love for Singleton, who she described as ‘the beloved, immediate friend / The chosen of my heart’.

properties.Name: The Greyhound Hotel (1990-2017)
properties.Story: The GH Hotel was built in 1853 and was renovated in 1938 to it's recognizable art deco facade. Known from the late 90s for it's drag shows, such as Show Bags, the GH became a landmark of queer life in southside of Melbourne. Closing in 2017, the site was demolished for apartments.

properties.Name: The Hub
properties.Story: The Hub was established in 1979 by Reverend John Willis of Christ's Community Church.  Used on Sundays for mass, the building was available through the week for other queer and non-queer community groups such as Society Five, the Australian Gay Archives (later Australian Queer Archives), Al-Anon, Alcoholics Anonymous and Transcare (a group associated with Seahorse). Elaine Barrie Project and Seahorse Victoria were among the groups that met at The Hub. Elaine Barrie Project was a second organisation supporting trans dressers. It was a spin-off of Seahorse founded c. 1979 and which met at The Hub once a month through the early 1980s. Elaine Barrie became unwell in the mid-1990s and the group changed its name to Chameleons and continued to exist until the early 2000s. The Hub also had a library of homosexual fiction and non fiction, which is now held by the University of Melbourne Library as the John Willis Gay and Lesbian Fiction Collection. The Hub closed in the late 1980s and was in many ways Victoria's first pride centre.

properties.Name: The Key Club (1978-1989)
properties.Story: Based in the Carlton Club Hotel, The Key Club welcomed the queer and hetersexual community on gendered nights.  Initially the site had a women only nights on Fridays, using the name Squizzies.  But after taking the name Key Club in in 1979 Fridays and Saturdays became a queer disco.  However this was to change again in 1980 to suit the needs of their audience.  On Thursdays the venue was women only, Fridays were a mixed event and Saturdays became male only.  The Key Club closed in June 1989.

properties.Name: The Laird (1980- )
properties.Story: The Laird is one of Australia's longest running gay-owned and operated venues, opening in 1980 by Ron Watkin and his partner David Allen. The masculine interior referenced the recently closed Woolshed, and was popular with the Southern Cross Motor Club, Jackaroos and Cruisers Motorcycle Club. This lead to various renovations to suit their ultra masculine patrons. In 1998, The Laird was approved to be a Mens only venue by VCAT and has become a safe haven for CIS and trans mens ever since.  Home of the Laird Leatherman Competition, various VicBears events and nights such as Spit N Polish, The Laird is a staple of the Melbourne Queer scene.

properties.Name: The Market Hotel (1984-2011)
properties.Story: The Market Hotel, now the Emerson, has hosted a variety of queer events and at one point was the epicentre of Melbourne drag.  Beginning as The Market Hotel (1984-1990), Ken Payne brought the Troll Dolls (Kerrie La Gore, Coco, Chanel and Timber) from Abbotsford to be the star acts of his new venue. This would not be the last of his collaborations with Kerrie La Gore, later developing 3 Faces at the same venue.  3 Faces (1990 - 1999) held elaborate and expensive drag productions, developing drag stars such as Paris, Rita, Miss Candee, Caresse, Tabitha, Sue Ridge, Barbra Quicksand, Doreen Manganini and Skye Brookes.  When 3 Faces closed in 1999, the venue transitioned back to The Market (1999-2011), a gay dance club. The venue would close in 2011, reported across media as the death of Commercial Rd's gay identity.  The Emerson took over the space and today is queer friendly, hosting a queer night on Sundays.

properties.Name: The Painted Pony
properties.Story: Make-up Classes. Featured in the February 1984 Seahorse Shopping Guide, this store/service was known to be Transgender and Seahorse Club friendly. The listings would also mention particular people to ask for, as they were known to provide safe experiences for the community. “Ask for Christine. Learn how to apply make-up correctly. It’s in comfortable private cubicles so there’s no need to feel at all embarrassed.”
properties.Source: Professor Noah Riseman, Australian Catholic University c/o Seahorse Victoria Shopping Guide

properties.Name: The Peel (1988- )
properties.Story: Following a rebrand of the venue, The Peel welcomed gay customers from 1988 and remains one of the oldest continuously trading pubs in Collingwood. The Peel is one of the few clubs in Melbourne that has legal exemption from the Equal Opportunity Act, acquiring this in 2007 after issues with hens parties taking over the venue. This exemption allows The Peel to remain and safe space for gay men. The 2020 lockdown of Melbourne in response to the COVID-19 outbreak nearly closed The Peel, but due to an outpouring of financial support for the queer community, it was able remain open.

properties.Name: The President Melbourne
properties.Story: Restaurants. Featured in the 1987 Seahorse Shopping Guide, this store/service was known to be Transgender and Seahorse Club friendly. The listings would also mention particular people to ask for, as they were known to be allies of the community.
properties.Source: Professor Noah Riseman, Australian Catholic University c/o Seahorse Victoria Shopping Guide

properties.Name: The Shrine of Remembrance
properties.Address: The Shrine of Remembrance, Birdwood Ave, Melbourne VIC 3001
properties.Story: On Anzac Day 1982, The Shrine of Remembrance e became part of Victoria’s queer history. A group of exservicemen climbed the stairs of the shrine to lay a wreath in honour of gay and lesbian people who had served and died in war. They were intercepted by the then Victorian state president of the Returned Services League, Bruce Ruxton and escorted away by police. Following laws lifting bans of lesbian, gay and bisexual people serving for our military (1992), as well as later changes allowing transgender people to serve their country (2010), in 2015 members of Defence LGBTI Information Service (DEFGLIS) and a a former member of the Gay Ex-Services Association laid their first wreath at Melbourne’s Shrine of Remembrance in honour of queer people people who had served and died in war.

properties.Name: The Star Hotel
properties.Story:
The former Star Hotel played host to many parts of the LGBTQI+ community.  
The Star Hotel held the first OutBlack event in 1995. OutBlack is Australia’s longest running Aboriginal and Torres Strait GLTBIQ & Sistergirls group, started as space for social support and solidarity for queers in the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander community, with their first Drag Show being in September 1997 and from that night the group began a respectful tradition of inviting Elders to attend all its events for free. The founding members of OutBlack were Ron Johnson (his alter-ego as the Grand Dame of the OutBlack stage Miss Yukeye), Michael Murray, James Mullet and Rhys Kinsey. For a number of years The Star was the preferred venue for OutBlack until the event became larger and more popular and required a higher capacity venue. 
The Star was also an important place for the Drag King community of Melbourne, hosting various events (such as King Victoria (2001 - 2008)) and being an important venue in the Abbotsford scene.

properties.Name: The Tease Salon
properties.Story: Dressmakers. Featured in the September 1980 Seahorse Shopping Guide, this store/service was known to be Transgender and Seahorse Club friendly. The listings would also mention particular people to ask for, as they were known to be allies of the community.
properties.Source: Professor Noah Riseman, Australian Catholic University c/o Seahorse Victoria Shopping Guide

properties.Name: The Victorian Pride Centre
properties.Story: The Victorian Pride Centre, opening in 2021, will be home to LGBTI community organisations and groups as well as advisory, health and support services. The site houses a variety of LGBTIQ+ community groups and organisations, as well as Peter Waples-Crowe's artwork 'Ngarigo Queen – Cloak of Queer Visibility'.

properties.Name: The Wailing Wall
properties.Story: Chapter House Lane was a known beat before World War 2, but when "The Confessional"came into being it received a new name, "The Wailing Wall"

properties.Name: The Wicked Lady
properties.Story: Dresses and Gowns. Featured in the September 1980 Seahorse Shopping Guide, this store/service was known to be Transgender and Seahorse Club friendly. The listings would also mention particular people to ask for, as they were known to be allies of the community. "Pleased to serve and advise Seahorse Members"
properties.Source: Professor Noah Riseman, Australian Catholic University c/o Seahorse Victoria Shopping Guide

properties.Name: Tony Briffa’s Mayoral Robes
properties.Story: Tony Briffa was first elected to Hobsons Bay City Council in Melbourne’s south-west in 2008 and re- elected two more times, serving terms as deputy mayor (2009–2010, 2010-2011 and 2017-2018) and mayor (2011-2012). She was the first openly intersex person to become an elected official anywhere in the world. Briffa’s election to local council, and later to the role of mayor, brought her continued public attention, as well as increased visibility and understanding of intersex people. Briffa’s mayoral robes represent her successful political career and, importantly, the fact that this career was achieved by an openly intersex person for the first time.

properties.Name: Tonya Designs
properties.Story: Dressmakers. Featured in the September 1980 Seahorse Shopping Guide, this store/service was known to be Transgender and Seahorse Club friendly. The listings would also mention particular people to ask for, as they were known to be allies of the community. Ask for Veronica.
properties.Source: Professor Noah Riseman, Australian Catholic University c/o Seahorse Victoria Shopping Guide

properties.Name: Transgender Liberation and Care (1995)
properties.Story: On the 3rd of May 1995, forty-five people attended the first meeting of the peer-led organisation, Transgender Liberation and Care.  Jonathan Paré and Sharon Saunders convened the meeting, inviting trans people to have their say, access support and education opportunities with the aims of assisting trans people to live a healthy and productive lifestyles. TLC went on to lobby the government, run education courses for workplaces and families about trans integration and supply advocacy for the trans community until 2002.

properties.Name: Treasury Gardens
properties.Story: Treasury Gardens was a popular cruising area from the 1920s.

properties.Name: Trish's Coffee Lounge (1970 -1994)
properties.Story: Trisha Barry (Jon Barry) ran Trish's, one of Melbounre's early drag bars. It was opened in 1970 and closed in 1994. Trish’s marked a transitional time in Melbourne’s queer scene, as people moved from secret meetings in hotels and cafes to an openly queer scene. As one of the few drag venues at the time, Trish's was the beginning location of many notable drag queens’ careers, some even going on to perform at Pokeys at the Prince of Wales. A night at Trish’s involved some questionable customer service as well as interesting performances as the often young performers refined their craft. Trisha is known for unhappily preparing food, such as toasted sandwiches, which had to be sold to get around restrictive alcohol licensing laws. Trish’s is looked back on fondly by many as a fun night of entertainment.

properties.Name: Ulms for Hair
properties.Story: Wigs. Featured in the September 1980 Seahorse Shopping Guide, this store/service was known to be Transgender and Seahorse Club friendly. The listings would also mention particular people to ask for, as they were known to be allies of the community. Make appointment with Ray.
properties.Source: Professor Noah Riseman, Australian Catholic University c/o Seahorse Victoria Shopping Guide

properties.Name: Unfolding of the AIDS Memorial Quilt
properties.Story:
In 1999 and 2001, the Royal Exhibition Building was used for the official unfolding of the AIDS Memorial Quilt. The Australian AIDS Memorial Quilt Project was founded in September 1988, inspired bt the American model (the NAMES Project AIDS Memorial Quilt). It consists of fabric panels created by people who have lost loved ones to HIV/AIDS. The panels are sewn together into blocks of eight. The project extends across Australia, with branches in all states and territories. Importantly, the Quilt was sustained by volunteer labour in each branch, until the time came to entrust it to organisations that could best care for it. The Victorian panels are held by Thorne Harbour Health (formerly the Victorian AIDS Council).
Each panel of the Quilt is unique, commemorating the individuality of the deceased with words and images that evoke particular interests or habits. The purposes of the Quilt are many, including commemorating the dead, assisting in grieving, and encouraging support for those living with HIV. But there are clear political aims, too: to bring a human quality to the statistics of loss and to promote a compassionate dialogue, to challenge discriminatory views, and to encourage HIV prevention.
properties.too: to bring a human quality to the statistics of loss and to promote a compassionate dialogue, to challenge discriminatory views, and to encourage HIV prevention.

properties.Name: University Club (1976-1981)
properties.Story: On the 7th floor of 100 Collins Street was the University Club.  It held mixed and men-only nights.

properties.Name: Val's Coffee Lounge
properties.Story: In the early 1950's Val's Coffee Lounge was a meeting place for both the heterosexual and queer community.  Known for its theatre and live music (Val Eastwood was the first to have in house shows), the business was booming and expanded to a two level venue after one year.  Although this doubled the seating to 160 but they had no problem filling the place.  Frequented by the queer community, but equally popular with artistic and theatrical people, Val's was packed every night.

properties.Name: Val's Restaurant
properties.Story: Val Eastwood, of Val's on Swanston and Ad Lib in South Yarra, opened her restaurant in the 70s.

properties.Name: Victoria Docks
properties.Story: The Victoria Docks were a popular cruising area from the 1920s.

properties.Name: Victorian Transsexual Coalition
properties.Story: In 1979, a group of trans women who attended a health conference founded a group called the Victorian Transsexual Coalition. This was primarily an advocacy group fighting for trans people who had surgery to be recognised in their affirmed gender and for anti-discrimination protections. They also ran a sub-group called the Victorian Transsexual Association Self-Help Group which, as the name suggests, was a peer support group for trans women who had or were planning to have gender affirmation surgery. At least one of the meeting places for the Victorian Transsexual Association was a private residence on Dandenong Road in Malvern. The archival trail for the Victorian Transsexual Coalition ends around 1975.
properties.Source: Professor Noah Riseman, Australian Catholic University

properties.Name: Wet on Wellington
properties.Story: On 10 April 2001, Wet on Wellington opened as a sex on premises venue. Wet has a flashy interior with Roman columns, statues, chandeliers, a full- length pool, a bar and outdoor terrace. Upstairs is a sex focused cruising maze. Although the venue's main clientel is men, Wet has played host to women-only nights, including MOIST, the ALSO Foundation’s Women’s only pool party and sauna night. They have also hosted Swingers' nights for heterosexual and bisexual people.

properties.Name: Whitehall Guest House
properties.Story: Whitehall Guest House was the location of of the weekend long 1973 National Conference held by the Radicalesbians.  The group was initially welcome, but when outed as lesbians were taunted by the owner's children and avoided by staff. Despite this, discussion papers about dealing with issues including monogamy, patriarchy, relationships, bisexuality, and feminism were presented.

properties.Name: Women’s Liberation Building (1988-1992)
properties.Story: The Women’s Liberation Building was a hub of political and feminist activity, housing the Lesbian Line and Lesbian Open House, as well as the Women’s Liberation Archives, which later became the Victorian Women’s Liberation and Lesbian Feminist Archives

properties.Name: Xchange Hotel (1986-2011)
properties.Story: The Xchange was the biggest drag venue in Melbourne during the 1980s-1990s with drag shows five nights a week. Some notable shows included La Gore's Back yard, Wonderworld with Doreen Manganinni and Jamie Lee, Anything Goes with Lucy Loosebox as well as Miss Cadee and Barbra Quicksand.

properties.Name: Yarra warves
properties.Address: 1 Convention Centre Pl, South Wharf VIC 3006
properties.Story: Before the site was the Melbourne Convention and Exhibition Centre, the warves on the south of the Yarra were a popular cruising area from the 1920s.

properties.Name: Yelena
properties.Story: Dressmakers. Featured in the September 1980 Seahorse Shopping Guide, this store/service was known to be Transgender and Seahorse Club friendly. The listings would also mention particular people to ask for, as they were known to be allies of the community.
properties.Source: Professor Noah Riseman, Australian Catholic University c/o Seahorse Victoria Shopping Guide

properties.Name: A different type of night out in Melbourne
properties.Story: Indie nights in Brisbane were always a straight affair. Words couldn't describe how much going to Q&A felt like home for a gay indie kid like me. I loved it so much, I moved to Melbourne in 2000!

properties.Name: A fresh start
properties.Story: Coming to Geelong completely changed my life. When I arrived here I was in the closet, was less than a year sober from a 19 addiction, no permanent place to call home and my mental health was very poor. I got involved in the YES vote campaign and through trial and error found the right health supports. I am now almost 5 years sober, started HRT involved in the local arts community, self-employed, have a partner, soon to be buying a home of our own. I am unapologetically visible as myself, a recovered addict, neurodiverse, disabled, and queer AF!

properties.Name: A new identity
properties.Story: My first move away from my parent's home in Sydney, NSW. A new identity that I'm still trying to resolve. A new job, a new state, new friends, new worries. I wish to help create nurturing communities in a state and city that has welcomed me with open arms.

properties.Name: A party of two
properties.Story: I was politically active at Melbourne University being on the University Assembly however I was somewhat an understated gay man. It was at Ryders that I first became aware that I was subject of discussion by a Melbourne University senior law lecturer as well as my attractive power (!).'Twas strange for me to even go to a gay bar as I found few gay men who attracted me. I was approached by the law lecturer who I recognised from the University Assembly. I was surprised he knew who I was. He asked if I would like to meet a well-known actor. They were ensconced at the back of Ryders from where they could talk in private and survey the dance floor.Apparently the actor had taken a shine to me and the lecturer said "I know him". Thus the approach & introduction. The actor plied me with drinks and tales from his career. Every introduction by the bar owner to another boy was rebuffed by the actor saying “Take him away. I'm with Gary". As the night ensued I was invited to a party at the actor's home in Toorak Road, Toorak; little did I know it was to be a party of two.

properties.Name: A Pride Brawl
properties.Address: La Trobe University Melbourne Campus, Agora Walkway, Bundoora VIC 3083
properties.Story:
In 1994, I was Women's Officer at Latrobe University Student's 
Representative Council. We organised an annual Pride Week - which was  -
 at times - an exhausting experience. In 1994, our events culminated in a
 pretty crazy brawl in the middle of the Agora when a far right 
Christian group came on to campus with a small amplifier to preach 
during our celebration.

properties.Name: A proud lesbian with an amazing Mum
properties.Story: I had just had the best night of my life. Dancing with an incredible woman, my first date with a woman. My parents up until this night had no idea I identified as a lesbian. I was 23. I was so high on the energy of finally being myself, in public that I could no longer wait to tell my mum. I had to tell her right then and there. So out the front, in the gutter at 12.40am I made the call. Mum frantically picked up “babe, are you ok?”... “mummy, I have to tell you something. I'm gay!” What she replied with has been burnt into my memory forever. “So? Are you happy?” I replied “yes! Very!”. So calm, so accepting. She knew. She knew before I knew. That one night in front of Love Machine cemented who I am. A proud lesbian with an amazing Mum.

properties.Name: A queer childhood
properties.Story: I had a number of strange exploratory childhood queer experiences at my parents' house

properties.Name: Adventures all over the big smoke
properties.Story:
When my mates moved to Melbs as young gay guys from Traralgon, they were both unemployed, having just finished up a fashion course at TAFE. Money was very tight as there was now rent to pay on top of everything else. I worked part time and was at uni. We would come up with ways to entertain ourselves on the cheap. It usually involved getting all gussied up in our goth finery, with big hair and make up, obligatory pvc pants and big platform boots. It was 2001,,, Often this was on a random night of the week, usually Tuesday or Wednesday. We would hop in my car and go driving around looking at the beautiful Italianate mansions near where we lived in Hawthorn. However, this night I speak of, we drove out to Bulleen and we went for a frolic in the sculpture gardens at Heide. Midnight in the Garden of Good and Evil, Melbourne stylez. We couldn't afford to go out much to gay bars and clubs (we preferred the goth clubs and Q+A) but we made our own fun in Melbourne's many parks, gardens and cemeteries after dark.  
We were safe as we could hope for and we would often stop for a kebab on Lygon or go for pizza at Topolino's in St Kilda. We were young and we had adventures all over the big smoke.

properties.Name: Alice Anderson's all-female garage
properties.Story: Alice Anderson, a famous female mechanic in 1920s, ran Australia's first all female garage in Kew. There is a book about her by Loretta Smith is called Spanner in the Works. Known to have masculine qualities and lesbian lovers. In 1926 she was shot in the head at age 29 in her garage under mysterious circumstances, some say she was murdered because of her sexuality

properties.Name: An Aromantic Realisation
properties.Story: After a long few days of discomfort in a romantic relationship, inner turmoil and reflecting on past experience, I finally realised on my daily commute that I was aromantic. It explained a lot, and I’ve felt so free in terms of my future and own heart ever since.

properties.Name: An eye opening night out
properties.Address: IQ at corner of Gertrude and Smith Street Collingwood
properties.Story: Growing up in the Latrobe Valley, it was a relative vacuum when it came to ethnic, gender or sexual diversity. In the late 2000s queerness was barely, if ever referenced in any curriculum or classes and certainly wasn't visibly acceptable for anyone. It was not until I went to my first Indie Queer (IQ) dance night in Collingwood that I ever saw other queer folks in any kind of number. People who looked and felt as I did, all mixing, colliding, sliding and grinding, yelling and meshing and cramming into every nook and smokers room cranny. It was invigorating and became an almost weekly haunt of a Thursday night, usually followed by a stumble down to the Peel and a further handful of hours dancing there.

properties.Name: An unhappy diagnosis
properties.Address: Pran Central Shopping Centre Mezzanine Level, 325 Chapel St, Prahran VIC 3181
properties.Story: I had been really sick for a while and I knew something was wrong.  I went to the doctors and was diagnosed as HIV+ after some testing.  It wasn't a surprise, but it wasn't the happiest news to receive.  I was lucky that by then there wasHAART and a lot of available support, I can't imagine what my life would be like if I had been diagnosed earlier when medication wasn't around.

properties.Name: Becoming comfortable with my gender identity and expression
properties.Story: 2018, This is when I uncovered and became comfortable with my gender identity and expression, and began identifying as non-binary.

properties.Name: BONEZ Alternative Queer Night
properties.Story:
In late 2017 I launched a dream of mine. I announced the first ‘BONEZ Alternative Queer Night’
I created BONEZ because I never felt truly comfortable at other Queer clubs and I knew so many other people would have felt that too.
BONEZ was created with the aim to provide a safe and unique space for our Queer community and to showcase Australian Drag, Burlesque and Music artists. 
BONEZ has since been a big part of the Queer and Music communities. Every year BONEZ releases a compilation of Alternative Australian Queer artists to raise money for Black Rainbow.

properties.Name: Commercial Road Memories
properties.Story:
October 2000. Just after the Olympics. I was out with a group of friends - including a guy I thought I was interested in who had come down from Sydney on his first visit to Melbourne - doing what mid-20s kids do, drinking, having fun. We started our night at Candy Bar in Gertrude St (not sure if it's there now). We were meeting more friends at Diva Bar up the road. As this was in the days of not everyone having a mobile phone another guy who was interested in me kept calling me from a payphone to see where we were given we were running later than planned. 

Anyway we eventually got to Diva Bar, and I was doing introductions. I was quite pissed so introduced the guy who was actually keen on me with the name of the guy I was interested in. Oh well. The night went on. We drank more, danced lots and had a ball. I'd had too much to drink, so had to leave. I was driven home by the guy who was keen on me. He stayed the night. We've been together ever since.

Commercial Road in Prahran was an important place in the early 2000s. It was a safe environment, generally, for the LGBT community. I miss that it's not there to be honest, given the spaces it provided, the sense of belonging it afforded, and the good times had.

properties.Name: Community Radio 3CR
properties.Story:
Friends were involved in Community Radio 3CR and in 1986 I joined a group of friends putting on the L&G show from 10.30pm to midnight on a Wednesday night. It was such a joy to be reporting on issues, events and activism in the community. Gay liberation, HIV/AIDS, Midsumma festival and queer politics were just some of the major things happening over the years the show was broadcast. The L&G show was the only lesbian and gay radio program in Victoria at that time.

The L&G show was relaxed and laid back with lots of information, banter and humour. But for some of our listeners who weren't out and living in unsupportive families it was also a lifeline. We received letters from listeners telling us they were listening in bed with earphones and that we were their only contact with the lesbian and gay community.

Once established we asked management at the station to turn the airwaves over to us for Stonewall Day, 28th June. For a number of years we did 24 hours of lesbian and gay broadcasting - it was exhilarating to fill a whole day with lesbian and gay content.

LGBTQI+ broadcasting has continued at 3CR and members of the community have played a major role in the management and staffing of the station and make up a significant part of the many volunteers who broadcast each and every week.

properties.Name: Crucible Tattoo Co.
properties.Story: I think queer people, especially the "newer" gen of LGBTQIA+ individuals, find a lot of power in visually identifying and marking our queer-ness. A space like Crucible, which features queer tattoo artists and is wholly inclusive of all races/genders/sexualities, really empowers peeps to emblazon themselves with art. The relationship between queer-ness and artiness is pretty obvious, but it's super cool to be in a space where talking about queer issues goes hand in hand with physically branding myself as a queer person.

properties.Name: DnM Bar and Nightclub
properties.Story: After seeing Nicki Minaj on her Pink Friday tour in 2012, I was invited by dykes seated near me to go to DnM! I had never been before but I will always remember the stuffy early 2000s feel and great music!

properties.Name: DT's
properties.Story: Dt's is an establishment that I've been going to since i moved here from far north Queensland 20 years ago.

properties.Name: First Gay Date
properties.Story: The first gay date I went on started at Flinders Street Station.  We met out the front and then went into the city for food.  It was nice but I remember being nervous.

properties.Name: First Kiss
properties.Address: Flinders Street station, Flinders St, Melbourne VIC 3000
properties.Story: Had my first queer kiss when I was 15 at Flinders St Station. We met on Habbo Hotel and travelled on the V/Line from our country towns in to the city. Still best friends 13 years later.

properties.Name: First Kiss
properties.Story: I had my first kiss here, first with a woman, first with anyone. We had been dating for a couple months but I was still so nervous to even touch her. Earlier on our date a boy had flirted with her and tried to ask her out. I didn't tell him we were on a date even though we were holding hands. When my train was about to leave she kissed me quickly and hugged me accidentally hitting me in the face and then ran away. I got on the train and sent her a text. She told me it’s not usually that awkward.  We have been dating for over a year since. We kiss and it’s never awkward.

properties.Name: First Kiss at Minus 18
properties.Story: My only other (also secret) queer friend and I had just turned 18 and were looking to sneak out of our rural town for a weekend a see what queer life in Melbourne has to offer. We found a Minus 18 event and decided to tell everyone we were going and staying in Melbourne for the weekend to go to Crown, but instead secretly went to a party as openly queer people for the first time. My more distinct memory was after I had my first kiss with another male, Bad Romance started playing and he did the entire choreographed dance whilst holding direct eye contact with me. At the time I had a lot of internalised homophobia from growing up in closeted in the country and I thought it was kinda yuck but I now actually think it was a vibe and would love to see him again. Going to a queer party as a queer man for the first time made Melbourne seem like it was full of such hope and wonder & cemented me moving here and exploring who I am.

properties.Name: First Kiss with a woman
properties.Story: The first time I kissed a woman was here. It may have been that I was incredibly drunk, but it was like no straight kiss I had ever had, and I didn't want it to end. It changed a lot for me

properties.Name: First Queer night at Thursgay
properties.Address: Mr Wows Emporium, 97B Smith St, Fitzroy VIC 3065
properties.Story: I moved to Melbourne after coming out as Queer/Bisexual wholly in my early 20s, Thursgay was my first 'queer night' experience with friends. I had the best night.

properties.Name: First time in Drag
properties.Story: The first time I did Drag was at DT’s annual Drag Ball. It was clear I wasn’t the only person who was in drag for the first time either. I won the discouragement prize for being too gorgeous.

properties.Name: Handsome Her
properties.Story: Lesbian owned business that introduced a voluntary man-tax to bring attention to the wage gap. A sight for lesbian socialising and activism. They had a wall featuring photos of feminist icons and menu items named after influential feminist figures. Short-lived, 2017-2019.

properties.Name: Homophobia
properties.Address: Flinders Street station, Flinders St, Melbourne VIC 3000
properties.Story: Some random man was walking passed my friends and I who were standing in the main area of Flinders Street chatting.  The station was busy and everyone was rushing around. He walked up so close to me and said faggot directly into my ear, not loud enough for anyone around to hear.  It sort of didn't feel real it was all so quick but I am sure it happened. I don't know why he felt he had to say that to me,it was the first time I had faced any homophobia

properties.Name: In Ya Face
properties.Story:
1992 - present. 
3CR Community Radio program"In Ya Face" is one of the longest running queer radio shows in Australia and has been on-air since 1992.
The program explores LGBTIQA+ narratives and news as they relate to current socio-political issues, including queer art, activism and advocacy, community, and personal experiences, from an intersectional and quirky approach. 
https://www.3cr.org.au/inyaface

properties.Name: Inner Queerness trying to get out
properties.Address: Victorian Trades Hall Council, 54 Victoria St, Carlton VIC 3053
properties.Story: I think the moment that I started to accept my true self when the gay marriage issue was in the media. I was just super invested and supportive of it and I just kind of realised; ... I think this is my inner queerness trying to get out

properties.Name: Liquorice AllSorts LGBT+ Group
properties.Address: Nexus Primary Health, 113 High Street  Broadford, VIC  3658
properties.Story: Liquorice AllSorts is a safe group for LGBT teens and young adults in Mitchell Shire. Being a country town it is rare to find this sort of group being run and being done well.It has made such a difference to those who have been able to attend and who need a safe place to attend living in a country area where they feel isolated and alone.

properties.Name: Lynx meetings
properties.Story: The one that means most to me is the Kindergarten in the old Craig Community Centre in Alamein (now Ashburton), where Lynx used to meet every Thursday night ... we had our own cupboard with our own books ! Some of us had no idea that there were books about us. We sat on little chairs, made coffee as desired: made real friendships. Interesting speakers, concerts, parties, dances, discussions, fun! ... $2 a time, affordable to all. Roster for 2 on the door - & that kept up for over 30 years! remarkable. There were other venues before I knew about it; this one late 1980s & thru 90s. We were ousted for renovations, so the old building is probably gone: Lynx moved to a Women's Centre in Holmsglen; much less pleasant. It is no longer marked in the Melway, so is probably extinct.
properties.made coffee as desired: made real friendships. Interesting speakers, concerts, parties, dances, discussions, fun! ... $2 a time, affordable to all. Roster for 2 on the door - & that kept up for over 30 years! remarkable. There were other venues before I knew about it; this one l
properties.so the old building is probably gone: Lynx moved to a Women's Centre in Holmsglen; much less pleasant. It is no longer marked in the Melway, so is probably extinct.

properties.Name: Melbourne Bisexual Discussion Group
properties.Story: The upstairs function room was the first venue for the Melbourne Bisexual Discussion Group on 22 September 2005. This community peer support group is still running every month, almost sixteen years later, though we've been in a few different venues since! (Currently on Zoom because pandemic.)

properties.Name: Melbourne Inclusive Church Reservoir
properties.Story: After hurtful and hateful comments from my church about my “lifestyle” I left and felt lost not knowing where to go to feel accepted.A friend took me to Melbourne Inclusive Church after seeing how much I was struggling and the difference between MIC and my old church was incredible. For the first time ever I felt like I had found somewhere that I belonged and where I could be myself.This church deserves so much more love and to grow so much bigger! The message that they are putting out there is amazing and it’s the perfect inclusive environment for LGTBQIA+ and Christians.

properties.Name: My Lesbian Wedding
properties.Address: Little Henri, 850 High Street Thornbury, Victoria
properties.Story: I married my wife here! For almost all of our guests, it was their first same-sex wedding and we turned it into the party-of-all-parties, with a "melbourne-cool" dress code, a live band and Taylor Swift as our first dance.

properties.Name: Naked Interruption
properties.Story: When I was 8, I went to Table Rock with a friend and their mother for a beach day.  We were playing mainly in the sand and water, but as the day progressed we decided we wanted explore the bushes.  We were having our fun playing a game when we were interrupted by two completely naked young men prancing through the shrubbery. They screamed when they spotted us and quickly moved out of sight.  It wasn't scary, just surprising. We didn't say anything, they didn't mean any harm and weren't doing anything inappropriate, we had just stumbled in at the wrong time. It took me years to work out that the men were likely queer, much of the shoreline was a meeting place for queer men and I imagine that those men were just enjoying being able to be themselves.  Being gay was illegal at the time, so it was kind of their only option.

properties.Name: Not just an experiment, I am definitely queer
properties.Address: Jimmy Watsons 333 Lygon St, Carlton, Victoria
properties.Story: I went on one of the best dates of my life with a wonderful woman. We saw each other for a few weeks. Then she ended it. Then we got back together. Then it fizzled away. But despite all that it was an amazing date, followed by incredible sex. Which was the best sex I have had with another woman and confirmed for me that previous sexual experiences with women were not an experiment or just a result of drugs/ alcohol. I do indeed really dig women and am definitely queer!

properties.Name: Our short history and our love
properties.Story:
Covid 2020 Vic Lockdown lead to a new date moving to Sydney at the end of 2020.
Our first dates in Fed Sq and CERES lead to 2 online dates that lasted for 6 hours each. A virtual connection
Cooking together, eating together and chatting all evening... lead to 3 months of the most beautiful love story of my life to date. Holding hands bolding, being called a picture of Art & Love in Elwood, joining hearts and connection over mental health, connection and feminist queer love,
That is our short history and our love xxx

properties.Name: Queer Space, Union House, The University of Melbourne
properties.Address: Union House, Tin Alley, University of Melbourne, Parkville VIC 3010
properties.Story: The University of Melbourne Student Union's Queer Space was a haven for so many queer students in many different ways. For many, it was the first place they could meet others like them, to be themselves or to start discovering who they really are. For me, it was a quiet place to study or take a break away from the crowds and noise of most of the campus, or even to take a quick nap. It was also somewhere I could meet new people, I even met a couple of crushes and flings. The Queer Department also had an annual Queer Ball in the city which was raucous fun. Uni is such an important time for students straight out of high school as we enter adult life and work out who we are. The student union, the queer department and the Queer Space helped me through that like so many students over decades.

properties.Name: Queer Virginity
properties.Story: I had sex with my first queer partner on the red couches, downstairs, during an MSO concert in 2015

properties.Name: Red Raw Parties
properties.Story: In the 90's we would go to the dance parties at the docks. They were wild and exuberant and full of joy. We would wear long coats to cover our outfits in the taxi so we wouldn't get harassed on the way there. But once we arrived, almost everything came off and we would plunge into the seething mass of beautiful dancing people. My girlfriend would be dressed in head to toe Versace. I was dressed in a see through  plastic skirt and gold body paint. Both of us flashing our Calvin Klein underwear. It was in the wake of the KD Lang/Cindy Crawford Vanity Fair cover so we were both long haired, glamorous and free.

properties.Name: Sauna Initiation
properties.Story: My first time at Wet I was a little overwhelmed.  It was so much to take in, so many bodies, so many signals and subtle forms of communication to learn. I don't even think I hooked up with anyone that night, I was just too green. I just walked around the maze trying to get an idea of the place and watched as people had sex publicly.  I was a lot more prepared the next time and had a much more active night.

properties.Name: Scirbbled Notes
properties.Address: Mount Evelyn Recreation Reserve, 70 Tramway Rd, Mount Evelyn VIC 3796
properties.Story: Graffiti in the men's public toilet, which appeared to be related to a hookup site somewhere nearby, was my first exposure to queer culture and desire.

properties.Name: Seahorse
properties.Story: Founded in 1975, Seahorse Victoria is the longest running support and social group for the transgender community in Australia.

properties.Name: Sneaking into clubs
properties.Story: Before I was 18, I used to sneak into Poof Doof in crazy costumes that hid my face. This was before they moved the door to the back entrance, the straights used to love seeing people so dressed up.

properties.Name: The Centennial Hotel
properties.Story: The Centennial Hotel was pub in Kensington that decided to change their clientele in the early 90s. Approaching local trans social and supports group, they developed a safe location that welcomed members of trans community to socialise and be in public as themselves.

properties.Name: The Fox Hotel
properties.Story: A cute spot for queers to eat and hang out! They have a good veggie menu and host a Drag King night every couple of months.

properties.Name: The Laird Hotel
properties.Story: I have been one of the owners of The Laird since 2007. The Laird was also the first queer pub i ever went to!

properties.Name: The Laird Hotel
properties.Story: A classic hotel built in the 1850s and became a gay bar in 1980.One of the oldest gay bars in Australia and has an exclusive men only admittance in recognition of its importance to the community during the AIDS crisis.The location has also supported leather and bear associations through its history.Famous visitors include Freddie Mercury and George Michael.

properties.Name: The only homosexual in the world
properties.Story: As a nervous but curious and lone (I thought I was the only one in the world) 18 yo homosexual in 1968, I had somehow heard that if I went to the small patch of beach to the left of St.Kilda Pier, I would meet others like me. It was the summer school holidays and after several Saturday afternoon visits I was approached by a slightly older man who invited me to come back to his flat nearby for a drink! The rest is history- it was my first sexual encounter with another gay man and there was no turning back.

properties.Name: Working Man Group
properties.Story:
Working Man is a membership based peer support group for Victorian male sex workers who provide services for male clients (M2M). The group has an ongoing membership of nearly 300 workers, built through a volunteer outreach program which has contacted about 3000 workers over five years. Working Man’s output includes the outreach program, onboarding and induction training, an ongoing chat support group, newsletters and information pamphlets on self-care and business acumen as well as social events and monthly support meetings at 4Bean Cafe in Northcote.4 Bean has a warm and welcoming atmosphere, friendly staff and a meeting room at the back to ensure the group’s privacy and confidentiality. The group has been meeting here on a monthly basis since 2016.

Working Man’s mission comes from the insights generated by a PhD research project, authored in 2013 by Andrew McLane, called “An Evolving Trade? Male Sex Work and the Internet.”

The name of the group, Working Man, is inspired by the title of a magazine, published between 1984 and 2001 by the legendary Prostitutes Collective of Victoria (PCV) called Working Girl / Worker Boy. The Collective was replaced by a community health program called Resourcing Health and Education (RhED) in 2001. Working Girl / Worker Boy was replaced by a similar magazine called RED Magazine. The Collective, spearheaded by champions of sex worker rights, including Cheryl Overs, was pivotal in changing the way sex work was, and is, perceived in Australia. The group’s mission began with the phrase “No bad whores, only bad laws” to highlight the mundane practical nature of sex-work-as-work, and the way discriminatory legislation targeting sex workers create, exacerbate and perpetuate violence against, and unsafe working conditions for, sex workers. 

The Collective was also a key actor in a number of community health initiatives, including needle exchanges to prevent STIs caused by intravenous drug use and the Sex Worker and HIV Project (1993/1994), a first of its kind in Australia. This project “gave a face to those individuals who had received a positive diagnosis, as a means to openly fight the ongoing discrimination against positive people in the sex industry” as well as “change community and industry attitudes towards positive sex workers to become one of practical support and informed choices, rather than reactionary fear and isolation.”(1)

1. RED (2001) “Knowing where we’ve come from” PCV Events:History, page 9
https://sexworker.org.au/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/History-of-PCV_-wiritten-by-RhED.pdf

properties.Name: Young, Gay Activism
properties.Story: I began attending gay liberation rallies at the age of 14 (1975) with a girlfriend who had come out to me as bisexual just before my coming out as a gay male. Our activism included a 'kiss-in' in front of the Australia on Collins building where the Woolshed bar used to be. We were the only high school students involved in the publication 'Young, Gay and Proud'. I spoke on an ABC radio panel about sex education in schools (my school librarian heard it!) around that time too. I was also a founding member of Young Gays, a social support group. I engaged in these activities without the knowledge of my recently migrated family, who were very religious and socially conservative. I was usually the only NESB immigrant at such political events. It was a heady and exciting time.

properties.Story: On my 16th birthday, I obtained permission at the Family Court of Australia to begin medically transitioning.
